DiscIP.211001.4:
The world outside the window is just starting to lighten.
The girl stirs, only half-wake.
Half-asleep, she senses someone approaching.
"... Trouble...?"
Her hand moves instinctively toward her sword, but then she hears two familiar voices that put her at ease.
"Amazing recovery. She took a really hard hit yesterday... And almost heals overnight."
"... Still, that doesn't mean she should charge in every time."
"Let's go shopping. There are deals on meat and vegetables today. Noya can have a proper meal and recover then."
"You say that, but she'll still be the one doing the cooking, won't she?"
"Well... it's not like any of us can cook as well as she can."

"Click—"
Just before sleep takes her again, she hears the door close softly, the sound carefully muffled.

The morning light leaves patterns upon the mist in the forest.
DiscIP.211002.4:
A gentle breeze drifts by, and another patrol day begins in the countryside just like always.
"What? The Shrubshrews are causing trouble again?"
The birds chirp their complaints to the girl, then take off toward the forest.

"Wait—hold up! I don't have wings, you know!"
She heads out, wind in her face, trying to follow the birds' path.
The afternoon sun washes over the endless wheat fields, wrapping her small figure in warm, golden light.

"Grumble, grumble—"
That's when she remembers that she's already missed her lunch.
"Ugh, this time I'm really going to teach them a lesson!"

Across the fields and over the streams, the little guardian of the forest sets out once again, full of purpose and fire.
DiscIP.211003.4:
The city quiets as dusk settles in, the sky glowing with iridescent light.

"Click—"
A camera shutter snaps somewhere above.
With a flash, the scene is caught and frozen in the lens.
A witch on a broom slips through the clouds, watching for the secrets hidden below.

"Oh? Isn't that the one everyone's been talking about lately? Love that expression~"
"Let's get one from this angle, too~"
"Whoops, guess they saw me. Well, I've already got some interesting shots!"
As night falls, the clever eyes behind the camera sparkle like stars, brightening the darkness above the city.

She looks quite satisfied with her unexpected finds tonight.
"Yep, you're going right on tomorrow's front page..."
DiscIP.211004.4:
Bubbles drift through her dreams, waves as soft as silk brushing the shore,
and every cloud glows with a gentle light.
She picks up her brush, dips it in paint, and sketches the reflections in the water, stroke by stroke.
Each line shimmers and sways with the current, and with every moment, her dreams ripple along with the waves.

—No matter how harsh reality gets, this place is always warm and calm.
As the waves rise and the clouds roll, the shadows in her heart are washed away like colors fading into the water.

The road to freedom really isn't as simple as she imagined.
Now that I've left the safety of my tower, is this the world I've longed to see?


She shakes her head, stands up, and shakes the water from her hands. With new resolve, she heads straight ahead.
—A princess who's left her castle won't be defeated by something this trivial!
DiscIP.211005.4:
"Oh, it's gone."
Without even realizing it, the girl has chased all the way into the heart of the desert.

As the legend has it, the long-haired cat that roams the Wilds can lead Trekkers to a hidden Monolith.
If you lock eyes with one, a secret path will appear.

A gust of sand sweeps by, and the quick little furball is nowhere to be seen.
The girl pauses for a moment, then lightly leaps onto the wind-carved rock behind her.
Dust swirls in the air; the endless sea of sand quietly keeps its secrets.

"Following those faint paw prints the whole way... I'm used to navigating the desert, but something about this place feels different.
Time seems to stand still here. It's like echoes from long ago are drifting on the wind. A strange feeling is welling up inside me..."
A ray of sunlight spills down, and her fingers freeze mid-tap on the keys—
She suddenly looks up and locks onto a pair of sparkling eyes in the distance.
DiscIP.211006.4:
To let go of her heavy thoughts, she opens the door and walks out into the serenity.
On this mist-soaked morning, sunlight filters through the leaves, and shadows flicker at her feet as she moves.

"Sorry I'm late."
The forest's residents are already waiting for her by the stream.
She runs over to join her friends. With each step, the anxious voice inside her becomes quieter.

"Let's take care of each other today, too."
She steps into the cool water, splashing as she likes, joy bubbling up inside her.
Playful creatures, swirling skirts—everyone is bathed in morning light, welcomed by nature.

No matter how chaotic things get in the outside world, this will always be her place to find herself.
DiscIP.211007.4:
"Why are you coming at this hour? We're about to close."
"And you want a temporary residence permit. We only handles long-term permits here."
A weary voice came from behind the glass.
After a brief pause, the employee pushed a booklet through the slot below.
"Here, take this and read it carefully when you get back."
"Seriously... Trekkers are such a bunch of country bumpkins."

Thinking back on yesterday's ordeal, the girl feels a bit annoyed, but there's nothing she can do about it.
Looking down at the city from the rooftop, the view below is as beautiful as ever.
She already knows the city's harsh reality.

Gazing at the city where she's about to make her mark, she finally feels a surge of courage.
"Just wait. One day... I'll amaze everyone in this city."
For once, she lets go of her frustrations and lifts her head high—
letting her hair and cloak dance freely in the breeze.
DiscIP.211008.4:
"Three letters from Emor, five packages from Philae... and twenty-five newspapers!"
She picks up her pen and checks off each item on her list one by one.
"All done. Everything's been delivered and all the fees are settled for today!"

As the sun slowly sinks below the horizon, she wipes the sweat from her brow and gazes off into the distance. 
A dreamy, small smile flickers across her face.

Look closely, and you'll see the answer in those bright eyes—
It's the joy of taking in this view after crossing so many mountain trails,
the pride of a courier who's worked hard all day,
and the boundless hope she has for the future after weathering so many storms.

"Nah, none of that."
"I was just thinking about how I should treat myself after all this running around. I'm exhausted!"
DiscIP.212001.4:
Snuffle—snuffle—
The feast is about to begin—

At the very front walks the brave one, their pointy hat shaped just like an ice cream cone—I bet it'd be perfectly crisp and crunchy.
The crawling magician isn't holding a wand but a lollipop you could crunch in one bite.
And you, long-haired weirdo hiding at the back of the line—I see you!
What's in all those bottles and jars in your pockets? I want to drink every single one!

Snuffle—snuffle—
They're climbing up onto the table—

Snuffle—snuffle—
They've spotted us—

One, two, three! Nobody's taking my bowl!
One, two, three! Don't break my plate!
Ready—ready—
Time to dig in—
DiscIP.212002.4:
"Hoho! Who's on duty today?!"
"I set three big fires yesterday, so I know it's not me!"
"Not... Glopo... Glopo... Gonna take a bath..."
"Snuffle—snuffle—"
"Hoho! Hey, lazy penguin, quit napping! It's gotta be you!"
"Those long-armed, long-legged ones are about to climb up! Get moving!"
"Snuffle—I swapped position with Cursipot—"
"Cursipot' on gate duty, I'm up top—"
"Hoho! Cursipot! Where's Cursipot?"
"That guy's useless, I'll do it myself! I'll burn it all, nice and clean!"
"Snuf—snuffle—fire, fire!!"
"Glopo... can't take... a hot bath..."
"Glopo... gonna melt..."
"Look! This is my blazing firestorm!"
"Hoho! Just go already! Don't get in the way!"
"Snuffle—put out the fire—put out the fire—"
DiscIP.212003.4:
What wonderful music that is.
What an enchanting rhythm.
Once you set foot in my domain, you must dance with me before you can leave.

Come, lose yourself in this grand, eternal, dazzling ball.
Come, surrender your poor, fragile, frozen body.
My drumbeat is your heartbeat.
My applause is your scream.
Why is your face so pale?
Why does sweat pour down your skin?

Come, come, dance with me.
Come, come, let me grant you sleep.
What an irresistible beat.
What a obsessive melody.
Once you set foot in my domain, you must dance with me—never stopping, never coming out from this frenzy.
DiscIP.212005.4:
Get fired up, get ready to move!
The hottest music is born from the fiercest flames!
Can't hear you! Louder!
Show me your passion, your anger, the ambition you're hiding behind those jokes!

That's it, just like that!
Give me your hand. Don't worry, you won't get burned.
As long as you play nice, I'll even let you touch my sharp claws—ever so lightly.
What's that? You think I'm "cute?!"
Hah, that's just because you haven't seen what I look like with my mask off~

Get fired up, get ready to move!
I still can't hear you—louder, let me hear it—!
DiscIP.212006.4:
I hear your summons.
I heed your prayers.
Those who once leaped over the heavenly gate have faded like smoke and cloud.
Those who defiled the throne still cling to the heights above.

You dare to meet my gaze,
You dare to pierce my armored scales.
Who gave you such courage?
Who lent you such strength?

Pitiful are you who have fools as honored guests.
And pitiful are you, the blind masses, who brand heroes as traitors.
Truth is hard to hear, and medicine bitter to taste.
The fate of the world—let it unfold, and watch in silence.
DiscIP.212007.4:
"Chirp chirp, chirp chirp."
"Did you hear? There's going to be a huge party in the forest, chirp chirp!"
"Awo! You almost pecked down my front door, first thing in the morning, just for this?"
"We already knew, awo! We even got invitations, awo!"
"Invitations? How come I didn't get one, chirp chirp?"

"Could it be... I somehow made the Forest Spirit mad without realizing it?"
"Awo?! No way, right? Didn't those Shrubrat leave an apple with the Spirit's name on it at your door?"
"Those Shrubrat must've slacked off again. I'll go tell on them to the Spirit, awo!"
"Apple... I think... I ate it."
"I thought it just fell out of the tree, chirp chirp."
"Dummy! Dummy!"
"You'd better bring extra snacks and bribe those hedgehogs at the door, awo!"
DiscIP.212008.4:
Bubbles, bubbles, swelling bubbles.
Splashes, splashes, endless splashes.

The most delightful time of the day again!
Set the temperature, grab a towel, and don't forget the rubber duck.
Turn on the music, rip open the snacks, twist the faucet wide.
Glug glug, fatigue melts away.
Drip drip, pressure goes poof.

Hot water is magic, strong enough to wash away every care.
The bath cures any and all worry.

In this rare moment of rest,
Glopo can finally put down the weight and title of the Glopo clan.
Even if a fearsome enemy drops from the sky,
they'll have to wait until Glopo finishes this bath.
DiscIP.212009.4:
At the dawn of life, where all desire begins...
I heed the ancient call and command the dice of fate.
Into the depths of the sea, I cast a silver coin.
At the edge of the heavens, I hang a single star.

I am the watcher beyond order, reside within the liminality of time,
listening to the greedy prayers of my faithful.
I sow seeds of fear, devour the power of belief, and abandon even the most devoted.
No one escapes my shifting labyrinth.
The endless repetition wearies me. A game with only one ending brings no joy.

Thus I take up the pen and rewrite the script of fate,
letting dreadful secrets spread through the world:
"Those who step through this door shall never return."
"Those who break this realm shall become unstoppable."
DiscIP.212010.4:
Is it finally my turn to take the stage?
It feels like I've waited forever for this moment; yet somehow, like it only just happened.
The curtain's risen on the final battle, and the chains of the arena clink in anticipation.
This is my stage, and I'll deliver a flawless performance.

Come on, show me everything you've got.
If you think I'm just some minor character, you couldn't be deadly wrong.
I'll catch every tiny crack in your defense.
Even if I'm knocked down, I'll get right back up,
waiting for the next challenger.
Even if I'm mocked, I won't care.
I'm no pitiful thing crying my defeat in the corner.
Who says the spotlight belongs only to the final room?
With me standing guard, this place becomes everyone's end.
DiscIP.213003.4:
"This is it! Our final performance."
"You mean our first."
"But... But if it doesn't go well, we'll have no reason to ever come back."
I curl up in the corner, clutching my guitar as the words stumble out of my mouth.
"If you're not feeling well, it's okay to rest—I can take care of things out there on my own."
"... No. I want to go on. Please, let me be a part of it."
I lift my head sharply, frustration burning in my chest.
But the moment I see her fearless expression, I shrink back again, burying my face even deeper.
"Just give me a little more time... If I try harder, maybe..."

"What you need right now is this!"
She suddenly pulls back the edge of the heavy curtain. Joyful, colorful light floods into our eyes.

And then I remember. That rainy night, walking home under my umbrella.
The street was dark and silent,
which only made the grind of my boring life feel even heavier.

In that moment, a guitar riff cut through the night like lightning.
It was sharp, electric, and intoxicating—
breaking through the rain, shattering the stillness—
That kind of color.

That's it. I'm going to chase after and reach for that color again.

"Let's go! It's our turn!" You grab my hand and pull me toward the light.
Scream, shake, burn!
Turn the longing in your heart into action.
This scorching night won't end!
DiscIP.213004.4:
Night falls, sirens wail.
The infamous Phantom Thief "Twin Moon," is on the move again.
"As the leader of the Special Task Force for the Twin Moon Case... Even if I'm the last one standing, I'll bring them in."
The helmet on her desk catches the glint of city lights bouncing off the skyscrapers.
She gears up and starts the engine—clearly not in the mood.

"Sis, I think there's some weirdo in armor on a motorcycle chasing us!"
"How could a tin can keep up with us? No way—watch this, I'll shout her off our tail."
"I don't think that's a good idea..."
"Hey, loser on the busted bike! You think you can catch us? Dream on! Enjoy the view from behind while you choke on our exhaust!"
"Skateboards don't really have exhaust, sis... Wait! She took off her helmet! I think she's aiming at us!"
"Huh? What is this, a Clichéin movie? No way—"
A loud crash, the clatter of metal—and the two thieves go tumbling.
"Two birds, one stone. Twin Moon is in custody."

"... Since you caught us, I guess we'll reward you by answering three questions."
"Hmph. We are—"
"Save it!"
DiscIP.213005.4:
Good evening, viewers. Up next, today's top story:
"Undercover Scoop! Flavio Idol Backstage Exposé!"
A special report brought to you by our field correspondent, Mistique...

"Hellllo? Anyone here?! My stage outfit only has the top half! Where's the skirt?!"
"Makeup! Who's in charge of makeup? Did you all do your hair yourselves?"
"Ugh, it's so stuffy... and hot... This place is way too tiny!"
The self-proclaimed professional reporter finds herself in a bind. In the cramped and sweltering backstage, her questions evaporate like steam, gone unanswered without a trace.
Everyone around her rushes past—if you take away their puffy skirts and flawless makeup, they'd look no different from the exhausted office workers she sees everywhere else.
"I knew it. Humans are such pitiful creatures. A bunch of burnt-out people put on fake smiles, just to please another bunch who are just as burnt out as they are."
The witch, with her sharp nose for news, suddenly gets an idea. A flurry of clickbait headlines flashes through her mind. This month's "Truth Award" is already as good as hers.

One second before the performance begins, she finally manages, through sheer willpower, to throw together a passable look for the cameras along with a color-matched costume.
The music starts. The curtain rises. The spotlight falls on her.
Cheers and applause echo all around, blurring her thoughts. Suddenly she understands why so many fight so hard to stay on this tiny stage.
"Humans may be pitiful creatures, but... When people carry their burdens together, the warmth and strength they find in each other is absolutely real."
DiscIP.213006.4:
"If you could make anything appear right now by magic, what would you want?"
"A giant treasure chest! No, wait, a map that shows where every treasure in the world is!"
"Some kind of winged vehicle, so delivering letters would be way easier... Maybe I'd call it an "autobird?"
"Hey! Can you guys be a little more realistic?"
Donna doesn't know whether she should laugh or cry. She drops her mallet, stretches her legs, and flops down on the ground.
The afternoon sun spills over her orange hair, making it look like a restless flame, flickering and growing with impatience. Her two teammates rarely follow instructions during their "renovation project"; they always end up doing their own thing, and that little out of scene conversation was just more proof.
Things aren't going well. The tall, blue-haired girl steps forward, shielding Donna from the blazing sun and hoping the tiny bit of shade will help keep their frazzled boss from totally losing it.
The other one curls up like a cat, crouching next to Donna and gently shaking her knee:
"Donna, I-I was just joking. Don't be mad... Ah!"
Teresa barely finishes her apology before Donna ruffles her hair even more, making her head look even more like a bird's nest.
"What, did I scare you two? Hmph, I'm not mad."
Both girls breathe a sigh of relief. The blue-haired one picks up the mallet from the ground, glancing at the mess they've made behind them:
"You two take a break. I'll finish the stairs for these two levels."
"Freesia, did you learn some kind of stamina spell? How come you never get tired?"
"I think that kind of magic does exist, but I don't know it. I'm just used to physical work."
"Waaah... Poor Freesia."
"Freesia, what kind of hard life did you have before this?"
The two girls on the ground hug Freesia's legs from both sides. She has to free her hands and, imitating Donna, gently pats them both on the head.
In that moment, she feels like she's learned a stamina spell after all.
It's just fixing up a train! She can totally do it!

"... By the way, what about you, Donna? What's your answer to that question?"
"Me? I was just thinking, if would be so nice if we had a huge bed, soft as marshmallow, so we could all get a good, comfy nap..."
DiscIP.213007.4:
In the beginning, we were one and the same.
Like paired feathers and entwined branches, we breathed the same air and listened to the same heartbeat.
Then we grew flesh, grew souls, grew horns.
I once thought life would never change, that fate was already decided.
We lived in darkness, in pain, in endless despair.
But you said we shouldn't accept that. You said we should climb upward, break through the barriers, and seek another world.
I didn't know what that other world was like; I was afraid of change, afraid of being torn apart, afraid of seeing you become someone I couldn't recognize.
But I remained your most loyal guardian, your truest companion, always following in your footsteps.

You told me there's a bridge at the edge of the world, spanning the abyss.
It snows all year at the bridge, bitterly cold. But if we cross it, we'll reach the far beyond.
Everything there should belong to us, and the people there would serve our kind.
—Because we were one, once.

The night before we set out, I trailed closely behind you, snowflakes falling into my eyes.
My steps grew lighter, my body nearly floating, and just before I left the ground, I grabbed your wrist.
The snow turned to clouds, wrapping softly around us both. The first wind of the new world brushed our hair; the birds sang together.
"Don't be afraid. We're almost there."
Suddenly, I realized it was only my illusion, a dream I couldn't put into words.
So I returned to reality, stood knee-deep in snow, with only your fade to black silhouette left ahead of me.
I summoned my courage to ask what exodus meant. You stopped, gazing at me from afar:
"If not for waking in the long night, the future could be ever bright."
DiscIP.213008.4:
"Wah—it's so cool in here—"
"Noya, close the window! I haven't finished stapling my ' Commission Handbook' yet, and it's gonna get blown away!"
"The wind is so strong..."
Travel is always full of surprises, and right now, the camper is brimming with both chaos and freedom.
"Okay, okay, I'm closing it!"
Under heavy fire, Noya hugs the steering wheel with one hand while hurriedly rolling up the window with the other, secretly leaving a little crack—she just has to.
"Iris, did you hit Noya on the head with our rice ladle just now?"
"Uh—I, I just grabbed whatever was nearby!"
"Now we're doomed. The god of food will punish us!"
"Our emergency rations will disappear, we won't find anything to eat out in the Wilds, and in the end we'll all starve to death in the camper..."
The terrified girl mumbles on, her imagination painting a grim future. Her voice drops lower and lower, picking up speed until the words blur into an unintelligible chant.
"Noya, pull over." 
"Iris has crashed again."
Amber, now a seasoned pro, steadies Iris by the shoulders in case she collapses. Noya opens the door, and together they help Iris out of the RV.
A cool breeze sweeps by and Iris sneezes hard.
"... I'm okay now."

When she comes back to herself, Iris slumps on the grass, rubbing her eyes. Not far away, Noya seems to be tinkering with something, but Iris can't focus on that. She's too busy reflecting on her meltdown.
It must be because she hasn't been sleeping well lately.
It must be because they haven't gotten any new commissions for two weeks.
It must be because...
Someone presses something warm into her palm. She looks down to find a steaming clay pot.
"Fresh soup! Drink up. You'll feel better after."
Their smiling chef winks at her. Amber peeks around Noya's shoulder, dangling a shiny piece of Tawny Nightingale in front of her:
"Iris, eat this bread. It's good."

Yeah, maybe things aren't so bad after all.
At least for now, she can finally take a real break.
DiscIP.213009.4:
Drip, drip—the sound of rain.
Light footsteps skip over puddles.
Raindrops burst at her toes.

Drip, drip—the melody of rain.
Hand in hand, they run through the rain.
Bubbles swirl in the air.

The rain sounds like music.
Every drop keeps its own secret.
Fluttering skirts look like flowers swaying in the wind.

The rain slowly fades away,
and bright sunlight returns to the sky.
A rainbow appears, rising and falling like their moods.

"The rain stopped right when we got home. I can't tell if that's good or bad."
"I think it's good."
"Eh?"
"Even while running in the rain, you were still smiling so much."
"... Go take a shower! You're soaked. If you don't take a hot shower, you'll catch a cold tomorrow."
DiscIP.213010.4:
I'm not sure when it happened, but I've turned into such a cautious person.
I worry that what I say won't come out right, that people will misunderstand me.
I worry that my solutions won't make anyone happy.
I worry... This outfit I'm wearing is too attention-grabbing.
"Is this dress... A bit too bright?"
She brought me this "Feather Robe" from the city, and it's supposed to be traditional Loong festival attire.
I choose my words carefully, not wanting her to think I don't like it and hurt her feelings.
"I think it looks great on you. Besides, you're on vacation. It's the perfect time to try something new."
"... Okay."
But even with her encouragement, I still feel awkward because I'm used to my usual work clothes.

The whole way there, my steps are awkward and stiff, praying I don't bump into anyone I know.
We pass a bun shop. We aren't even hungry, but the chef's skill is mesmerizing.
With his left hand, he wraps the thin dough around the filling, spinning it effortlessly,
while his right pinches the top closed with even, perfect folds.
I count them quietly: exactly eighteen.
In no time, the whole tray goes into the steamer. She glances at me.
"There's an ancient saying that 'Doing great things is like cooking a small dish.' You can apply the cooking lessons to life. Do you know what's the most important thing?"
I try to ignore how young she looks saying that and focus on the steaming buns.
"...Is it the timing?"
"Nope! It's being happy!"
"Huh?"
"Sure, timing matters, but if the chef isn't happy, how are the customers supposed to feel happy? Right, chef?"
The chef bursts out laughing.

"The most important thing in life is being happy..."
I repeat her words to myself as I spot a shop I haven't visited in ages.
"Hang on, wait for me."
Might as well do something that makes me happy.

"One bubble tea, full sugar, less ice. Thanks."
The steam from the buns fogs up the neon-lit street
while the humid air beads cold drops on my cup.
For now, I let myself put all my worries aside
and start enjoying this minute that's all mine.
DiscIP.213011.4:
The girl lingers in front of the token exchange machine.
"This machine only accepts exchanges for 5,000 or 10,000 tokens"—the bright red message scrolls across the screen over and over.
She glares at those two numbers, gripping the only 1,000-token voucher she has.
Oh well, guess she'll have to pick up a couple more shifts at the convenience store and save up before coming back.
Who knows if that stingy boss of hers will find some new excuse to dock her pay...
She pulls her cap low, slipping away like a general dishonorably retreating from the battlefield without a fight.
Suddenly a hand lands on her shoulder from behind, soft and steady, as if reaching out to the part of her that refuses to give up.

"Cat-ear hat, pigtails... you're Chaton, right? The number two on the arcade rankings?"
It's a voice that she doesn't recognize. It's full of confidence and totally out of place in this noisy arcade.
Maybe she's here to challenge her? Fine. Let's see if she can bluff her way into a free match.
The girl tries her best to look tough, answering in a voice even louder than the stranger's.
"That's me. If you want a match, you're paying."
"Sure. Five rounds, to start."
Seriously?
Surprised, the girl looks up and meets the challenger's gaze. She finds a pair of perfectly calm crimson eyes.
This one's long hair is tied back, and unlike the usual challengers covered in over-the-top studs and spikes, she's just wearing a plain jacket.

"As a rank holder, I will only play against you if you state your name!"
"I'm Kasimira."
Kasimira...
Of course Chaton knows that name. She's seen it above her own on the leaderboard more times than she can count.
Kasimira, the number one.
All her bravado deflates like a pricked balloon.
"Give me a break. The ranked number one came all the way here to stomp on us losers?"
Kasimira doesn't answer. She fishes in her pocket and presses the exchange button.
"I've watched your replays. Your tactics are interesting."
Five tokens appear in Chaton's palm, the crown side facing up like an invitation.
"Want to play a round?"
"Of course."
DiscIP.213012.4:
The bike's dim headlight glides through Ash District, restless and alert,
scanning the streets like a judge at a talent show, eager to spot tonight's next act.

A sudden reflection blinds the rider for a second and she almost loses her balance.
Once the daze passes, she sees them: three girls in school uniform,
innocent-looking but blending into the night as if they belong there.

"Platinum Academy, huh? It's already past curfew. What are you doing under the Waterway this late?"
"Hmph, isn't it obvious? We were just—wait, ah!"
"Time to go home, sis~ Sorry, officer. Our study hall ran late and we have just finished up."

The rider moves to pull out her notepad behind her back,
a small gesture that instantly puts the girls on edge.
"Wow, you all look nervous. Don't tell me your school still does corporal punishment?"
The rider shuts her notebook with a snap, climbs back on her bike, and lets the engine rumble.
"Be smart and don't wander at night. I'll let you off this time."

"Hey—"
The girl's voice, young but clear and loud, makes everyone freeze on the spot.
The rider's hand hovers over the siren switch as she checks her rearview mirror.
"Wear goggles when you ride at night—"
The leader crosses her arms, meaning well, but it just gets under the rider's skin.

"... Tch. Mind your own business."
She revs the throttle and heads off toward Silver District without looking back.

"Whew... She's finally gone. You were so cool! Not scared of her at all!"
"Keep it down, sis. We almost got caught."
"I did laundry, but who knew the fake uniforms would come in handy?"

The girls turn and pull down the cloth cover hanging on the wall—
revealing their latest creation, finished just tonight, a splash of color that belongs only to them under these stars.
DiscIP.213013.4:
The story began in the forest on a moonless night.
Someone who smelled just like her left both me and her behind in this unfamiliar place, and she was just a baby.
The forest's colors changed, pale to deep, over and over again.
And as the seasons turned, she came to look and smell more and more like that woman.

"What are you smelling, Coco?"

I wander over to a little nest made of maple leaves, pretending not to care.
She follows and flops down next to me, gently running her hand through my fur.
Just like that night. Just like back then.

"Is it the maple leaves? Let me try!"
"Yeah! Smells just like the fall season."

The colors of the forest shift once more.
DiscIP.213014.4:
Kaydoke is in her workshop, performing routine maintenance on her tools.
A tender smile spreads across her face as she polishes her "treasures."
The peace is shattered by the arrival of a blonde girl.

"Hey there! Sorry to barge in!"
"... Yo, Tilia. What brings you by?"
"Lapis Eagle's been acting up again. I was hoping you could ... take a look?" she asks, scratching her head sheepishly.
"Again? Let me guess... You pushed it too hard chasing those Ashwind punks, didn't you?"
"Rushing over the rough terrain of the Ash District for way too long?"
"Whoa, spot on! You have your own intel network or something?"
"Hardly. This is the fourth time this week."
"Heh heh..."
"You're hopeless. Bring 'er in."

Kaydoke gets to work, focusing on the Lapis Eagle before her.
After a moment, the blonde girl pipes up.

"So, um..."
"Hm?"
"Since you're taking it apart anyway, could you maybe also..."
"No."
"Huh? I haven't even says anything yet."
"I know exactly what you want. Some kind of glowing, transforming armor, right? Or maybe bolt-on weapons or an extra engine?"
"So that's a no?"
"Of course not. This is a patrol scooter! Look, what happens if you make a little kid wear a full suit of Imperial Guard armor?"
"They'd ... become a little knight?"
"... They'd get crushed by the weight of it, right?"
"Oh! Right! I guess they would."
"It's the same for your scooter."
"Adding all those flashy mods won't improve its performance. It'll just weigh it down."
"I see... Have the other knights really never asked for stuff like that?"
"You think everyone's like you?!"

With the Lapis Eagle fixed, Kaydoke walks Tilia out.

"Thanks, Kay! Oh, this is for you."
"Is this ... taiyaki?"
"Yep! From that new dessert shop.
Their taiyaki is amazing, and I wanted you to try some."
"Oh, thanks. You didn't have to.
Anyway, try to take better care of your Lapis Eagle. If you wreck it again this week, I'm not fixing it."
"Three days! Can we make it three days? I swear I'll make it last longer this time, please, Kay?"
(Sighs)

The boisterous blonde finally leaves.
The paper bag holding the taiyaki rustles in Kaydoke's hand.
"It's already gone cold from the ride over!"
DiscIP.213015.4:
Deep down, Nazuna knows she is filled with regret.
Even someone as lazy and unmotivated as her, who only ever wanted to coast through life...
... has something she desperately wants to protect.

A single missed chance can last a lifetime.
Longing can never bring back what's gone.
Like the falling rain, the wandering birds, the friends who drift away,
and a familiar scent. Everything fades...

After Nazuka decided to leave, Nazuna stepped in to keep her room tidy.
She volunteered for the chore, taking on the persistent work.
For a long time after, Nazuna just couldn't get used to the emptiness.
Every laugh with Kaede, every trip into a Monolith, every meal at home ... it always felt like someone was missing.
Had her friend found new people to rely on? Someone new to treasure?
Nazuna wasn't sure which answer she feared more. "Yes" meant she was alone. "No" meant her friend was.

Whenever Nazuna went to the affairs office or the camp, she would quietly check on the Wandering Birds.
Her friend's guild grew more and more successful. And while Nazuna was genuinely happy for her, each success was a painful reminder of the distance growing between them.
As Nazuka took more jobs out of city, Nazuna lost the heart to join the crowds, choosing instead to hole up at home.

If I just get one more chance, I won't miss it again.
But she is a coward. The truth is a secret she only dared whisper to herself, swallowed by her blankets.

"Where are you?"
"What are you doing...?"
"There's ... not a single trace of your scent left in this room."
DiscIP.213016.4:
"Magnificent! Miss Befana, hold that pose and look right this way!"
—Do you see it? The audience's hungry stare.

"I'll never forget tonight's performance! I'm definitely coming back tomorrow!"
—Do you hear it? The same old cheers.

Fleeting lights flickered.
Heartfelt cries echoed.
She accepted their searing, sincere gazes,
pitying the devotees who had traveled so far to see her.

So what if their love was false?
So what if her bloom was fleeting?
Come, offer yourself as nourishment to the one and only blossom.
In this paradise that welcomes all, there is only intoxication.

She looked up as the rose that never sleeps swayed and shed its petals—an offering, or a sign of decay?
The roar of the crowd faded. Through the curtain, she felt the final warmth seep away.
Only her beating heart reminded her she had not yet become a perfect marionette.

Back then, had she been trapped in the same dream as everyone else—one she never wanted to wake from?
DiscIP.213017.4:
"Two-minute break. Let's take it from the top."
"If you can't keep up, practice on your own time. Don't drag the whole group down."
All eyes in the room fell on Ophir. She looked down, pretending she hadn't heard as she tightened her shoelaces.
It's to be expected, Ophir told herself. A beginner practicing with idol trainees is bound to get called out.

When the TV station announced an idol competition, Ophir signed up. She never expected that on top of hosting, she'd also have to compete as an idol for a debut spot.
"Viewers are sick of the same old idol competitions. A fresh format is the only way to boost ratings."
"Idol versus idol, idol versus host, host versus host... The competition, the clashes... Just thinking about it gets my heart racing."
She recalled the hunger she saw in the station director's eyes as he spoke—like a shark scenting blood. If she were just starting out, a chill would have run down her spine, and she might have even quit.
But after years in the industry, she is used to its rules: capture the audience's attention, make them smile. That is her job.
No use overthinking it. Skip dinner, find an empty studio, and practice. The years of grinding has taught her to bounce back fast. She glances at the mirror, where the faces around her blur into one.
But the raw pride in their eyes as they stare at their own reflections—that is unmistakable.

She suddenly remembers a question Mistique had asked when they were first paired up.
"Ophir, what's your dream?"
Back then, she had just learned not to wear her heart on her sleeve. She summoned her courage and countered:
"Tell me yours first, and then I'll tell you mine."
A flicker of surprise crossed Mistique's eyes before she wagged a finger, a sly smile on her face.
"Dreams are for ordinary people. A witch like me can achieve anything she desires."
True, I am ordinary, Ophir thinks. But I refuse to stay that way.
It is that refusal—that fire—that keeps her going.
She is going to become the greatest host in Flavio. No matter how long it takes.
DiscIP.213018.4:
Her favorite soda is sold only on certain holidays.
Today is the day Cosette has been waiting for—her special soda run.

The store is overflowing with every kind of drink imaginable.
New yogurt flavors are in. Strawberry sounds too sweet, and multigrain ... would that be chewy? As for original, she hasn't touched it in ages.
Cosette wavers in front of the cooler before grabbing one of each flavor.
The juice selection offers nothing new. She is tired of the usual options, but then she remembers a trick she'd seen at a café: adding sparkling water to juice.
Maybe I'll give that a try?
She places two bottles of juice and sparkling water into her basket.
The basket begins to feel heavy.

A new product lines the left shelf. The sign proclaims it is a rare find from a Monolith—a powder that dissolves in water to become a delicious drink!
Should I try it?
She's never tried anything like it. She picks up a box labeled "Instant Coffee" and places it in her basket. It's so expensive—three times the normal price!
I'd cry if it tastes bad...

At last, she reaches the soda cooler, home to what she's been looking forward to all holiday: melon soda!
Made with melons from the south, an exclusive summer fruit, its sweet fragrance danced on the bubbles. One sip is all it takes to taste the essence of summer.
Three bottles? That won't be nearly enough. Half a dozen? Six, one a day, will last until next weekend...
But will they still have this flavor next weekend? If she buys too many, they may expire before she could drink them all...

Cosette dithers in front of the cooler before finally adding five bottles to her basket. It's already so heavy; any more and she won't be able to carry it.
She doesn't know if melon soda will be back next holiday, but even if it isn't, there will always be other flavors.
Cosette knows that come next holiday, a new soda will be waiting for her.
DiscIP.213019.4:
Some patients would lie to their physician habitually.
"I've followed your orders, Doctor. Haven't touched a drop in two months."
—Then what's that slip of paper that just fell from your pocket? The one with the tavern's logo on the back?
"I-I don't remember where I've been, or what I did... Look, I came to the clinic, didn't I? What's with the interrogation? I really can't remember, doc..."
—He takes out his frustrations on the very family that cares for him, performing a one-man farce that can't even convince himself. An absurd little show, staged just for me.
"It's just a minor issue, no need for a prescription. Besides ... my family can't really afford it..."
—She hides her illness out of misplaced kindness, dooming her family to the worst possible future.

This little clinic is flooded with lies. They spill from countless mouths,
clinging to my skin, covering my mouth and nose until I can barely breathe.

Just as I began to sink into this vortex, my fingertips grazed something cold.
—A skeleton.
A silent witness.
I traced the fractures in its bones, revealing the trauma it suffered in life.
I studied its form and pieced together the story of its death.
Without the interference of deceitful words, the truth was laid bare before me.
So clear. So beautiful.
Ah ... it drifted into my chest and consumed the lies that held me captive.
That was the feeling of being reborn.

Year after year, I traveled far and wide, collecting countless skeletons.
But in the deepest corner of my collection, one specimen is still missing. It will be the most beautiful, the most pristine, the one I simply must possess.
And I am waiting.
DiscIP.213020.4:
A torrential downpour hammered the house while the wind shrieked, threatening to tear the roof from its walls.
The lock rattled. Terrified, the girl pressed her ear to the door.
A heartbeat passed, then another, before a heavy force slammed against the wood.
She threw her weight against the door as she fumbled with the deadbolt. It clicked shut, and the pressure on the other side vanished.

They'll give up now, she thought, but soon, that thought proved naive as the wall beside her was shattered.
A shovel blade burst through from outside, spraying wood splinters across her face.
For a split second, as she wondered why her own shovel was in the hands of an intruder, the horror crashed over her like waves. She was a wreck.
The shovel twisted violently before being pulled back through the hole. Where would the next blow land? On her head?

Ridge jolted awake from the nightmare. The plundered storeroom isn't just a dream, she realizes, but a real and constant threat.
Before, a "ransacked cellar" has been merely a phrase. But having seen the horrifying vision, she now understands how such a disaster could drag her life into an unknown abyss.

A cold sweat breaks out on her brow. She resolves to repair all the cellars first thing in the morning—hide the entrances, reinforce the walls, add inner doors...
The ideas flock through her mind like birds. But whenever she tries to seize one, the entire flock scatters, and the plans dissolve like scattered feathers.
Every solution remains a fleeting thought, lost on the edge of her next dream.

Her terror and anxiety subsides, leaving only the soft patter of rain against the window.
By the time the sky pales to dawn, Ridge is fully awake, the night's disturbance swept away by the howling autumn wind.

She blinks her heavy eyes open. Life goes on.
DiscIP.213021.4:
Gaze into the mirror. What do you see?
A past marked by defeat? A present sunk in routine?
A future lost to the shadows?

Close your eyes. What do you recall?
The soaring vows you once made? The faith now worn to the bone?
The friends who vanished on the road?

When you were born, who first rejoiced?
Who first wept at your side?
Do you remember your first touch of warmth?

If you vow to go on, please face this mirror.
Cast off your guarded disguise. Bare your frightened soul.
I have heard your whispered prayer.
To the devout, all wishes are heard.

Take the stage, and the prophecy will live.
You must only endure. You must survive.
Though crushed by your foe, you must claw your way up.
Shatter your chains. Break the rules of their game.

Your pain is a sign you are on the right path.
This is the trial you must face. The road to your truth is paved with scars.
Cast your doubts to the wind. Plunge into the magma of your ordeal.
In the last breath before the fire takes you, despair will crystallize into hope.

When you close your eyes a final time, the prophet's words will come to pass.
I will cover your broken shape with fallen blossoms,
as the flame in the mirror gutters and dies.
Do not fear the loneliness of the Underworld.
For one day, we will meet again.
DiscIP.213022.4:
The stage is set, as destiny sounds its horn.
You make your entrance, a challenger reborn in desire.
Come with me. I promise you a love beyond all measure,
my flickering lantern a beacon to your triumph.

I will dab the sweat that beads upon your palms,
and smooth the collar that rests upon your neck.
Doubt not. I alone can pierce your heart's dark corners and stir the desires deep within your soul.
Hesitate not. The star atop the Monolith has always belonged to you.

In the arena, no one is invincible. One loss says nothing of your true power.
The key is still within your grasp. Will you not turn it in the golden lock?
Listen to me. This is no time to falter.
That moment the spotlight finds you ... it feels sublime, does it not?
And I will always be at the pit, watching from the darkness—your most devoted fan.

When you grow weary, I will be your comfort, your confidant.
Perhaps we'll play a little game where all the rules are blurred.
But I will be the one who wins, and you will take the stage again.
Just hold on. Everything you crave is almost within your grasp.

In days without you, I caress your phantom in the flickering reruns,
and wonder in whose room you now reside.
I have bound your secrets in a shimmering cipher,
and buried my curse in the deep, dark base of the tower.
"You won't forget me. You still need me."
DiscIP.213023.4:
A girl opened her eyes to a world of pure, unending white.
The silence was absolute. There was no trace of life here.
As she drifted through the void, she felt the nagging sense of a vital duty she had forgotten.
To escape the emptiness, she let herself fall back into a deep slumber.
Ages passed in the world outside, but she remained untouched by time, simply waiting.

After an eternity, visitors finally arrived in her silent land.
From the shadows, she watched as lone figures became crowds, their rags turning to armor, their hands to weapons.
She was sure they were nothing alike. All she could do was watch from a distance.
But in a place where so many wishes converged, nothing stays the same forever.

One day, a Trekker, covered in wounds, suddenly appeared before her.
He was so weak he was on the verge of fading into the silent void.

"Are you ... a divine messenger? Is this ... the end?"
"No. You've failed. The peak is still far from here."
"I see... Are you here to take me away?"
"I'm sorry. I can't do that."

Her reply was cold, but he seemed to have misunderstood. A flicker of hope sparked in his hollow eyes as he weakly raised a scarred hand.

"Then ... please, save me... I don't ... want to die yet..."

At that, the girl finally understood her purpose.
She knelt and gently tended his wounds, her touch as soft and natural as a white feather settling on his shoulder.
She vanished before he awoke, leaving the Trekker to believe his survival is a miracle.
She thought that would be the last she saw of him. But he returned, again and again, always bearing new injuries that left her at a loss.

"That thing in the armor fights dirty. I swear, without the armor, it'd be no match for me."
"A friend of mine plucked the star the other day. I'm so jealous."
"Ever been to the great desert? I tried cooking sand scorpion once. The taste was ... something else."
"I've scaled mountains, crossed plains, and climbed Monoliths ... but sometimes I still get homesick. Did you know, the night sky back home..."

The girl never answered. She just healed him in silence.
After she found her purpose, more and more strangers found their way to her space.
They loved to talk of the world outside the Monolith and the trifles of life, but it all meant nothing to her. She found her meaning only in the Trekkers who spoke to her after she healed them.

More time passed. One day, while tending to a Trekker as usual, she looked up to find an old man on the verge of death.

"After all these years ... you haven't changed a bit."
"I know you. Your life is fading."
"Heh... There's time enough for the grave once I'm done with this."

The old Trekker pulled a wooden box from his coat. It held no treasure, only a single feather of pure, immaculate white.

"No one will remember you. Everyone ... they always move on ahead of you."
"But I searched my whole life and finally found it. A feather which color will never fade. Just like you."
"I always hoped ... I could leave you something."
"You're running out of time. You should talk less."
"Heh... Thank you..."
"Thank you for saving me that fateful day."

The girl gazed at the pure white feather that would never decay.
That day, her silence lasted longer than ever before.
DiscIP.213024.4:
The clerk sits behind the counter, counting the minutes until closing time.
A Trekker hurries into the convenience store.
"Hey, back again?"
"That last Artifact must've sold for a good price. Trying your luck for another?"
"Alright, then. But wishes from the Monolith ... they always come with a price."
After the last customer leaves, the clerk wonders how to kill the rest of her shift.
"Restock the shelves? Nah, that can wait."
"Clean up? It'll just get dirty again."
Her mind begins to drift.
(Yawns)
A yawn escapes her—the price of gaming all night.
Slowly, the shelves of merchandise blur into the landscapes from last night's game.
"That's the outpost, this is the plains ... and oh, that's..."
Her gaze finally settles on a shopping cart sitting alone between two aisles.
"Hey, isn't that the four-wheeler I built with Crystalum last night?"
The clerk stands and walks toward the cart.
With every step, the weariness seems to lift from her shoulders.

A girl approaches the store's entrance.
"It's pretty late. Is Portia still here?"
"Whoosh—"
A strange noise from inside makes her pause.
"Did someone just ... drift inside the store?"

Shaking her head at the absurd thought, she pushes the door open.
The clerk is back behind the counter, wearing her usual tired expression, though her hair is a mess.
In front of her, a shopping cart slides to a halt.
Its wheels have left a looping trail across the floor—
the marks of a stolen moment of freedom.
DiscIP.213025.4:
"If you had to live one day from your past on repeat, which would you choose?"
Under the spotlight, the pink-haired girl flashes a subtle pair of fangs. She hits replay on the player and sways to the hypnotic music.
"I don't know. Does it matter?"
The silver-haired girl polishes a thorn-rimmed mirror, her expression flat as a sharp edge grazed her fingertip.
"Tch. Such a stick-in-the-mud."
A mischievous thought sparks. The pink-haired girl lifts her lantern and creeps behind her companion, a hazy orb of light pulsing between them as she begins her usual ritual—the one for challengers about to take the bait.
"Tell me ... what is it you desire..."
"Show me ... your truest self..."
But the lantern doesn't flicker. Her target holds no desire for it to find.
"Thanks for the light. The mirror's clean now."
The silver-haired girl has long grown used to her companion's theatrics. This same scene has played out countless times over the years.
In its own way, their life is already on repeat.

"Tell me, why do people risk everything for impossible dreams?"
"It's human nature. And their greatest weakness."
"Or is it that our methods are so good they can't help but fall into our trap?"
The pink-haired girl gives a proud toss of her head, setting the rabbit ears on her costume bobbing. When she wears this outfit, almost no one can refuse her invitation.
She never understood why, but she never lost.

The silver-haired girl recalls the eyes of all the challengers—the defiant, the desperate, the determined. They all came with different wishes. They all walked the same path.
She can't understand it either, but she sometimes wonders why.
"Honestly, even without us ... they'd pay any price for their so-called 'dreams.'"
"We just give them a little push."
"And that's what's most terrifying about them."

"Bernina, could you fix my bow tie? I think it's loose."
To this day, Virigia still hasn't gotten used to the outfit. People would calmly discuss their deepest desires with her, but the moment she turns away, she can feel their stares burn into her back.

The sound of hurried footsteps draws near. Their appointment has arrived. It is time to go.
DiscIP.213026.4:
"Heeey, hey, heeeey! Different day, same channel! Thanks for tuning in to see your girl Beatrixa again, my little gems! ♥"
Beatrixa always went live right on schedule, but today was different—her stream started twenty minutes early.
Despite the sudden start, her eager fans were already there, refreshing their pages. A flurry of comments soon filled the chat, and the stream buzzed to life.
"Alright, my little gems! To spice things up, I'm introducing a special new segment today! ♥"
The stream's view switched from the arena to a blank text screen.
"You've all had a long day and are probably feeling tired and frustrated, right? Bringing that negativity in here's just gonna ruin the fun. So—I'll fix that for you!"
"Go on, post whatever's bugging you in the chat! Of course, I'll be prioritizing Super Chats."
The moment she finished speaking, viewers flooded the chat with the day's misfortunes.

"Thanks to 'NeedANewStart' for the SC! 'My crush rejected me today. Beatrixa, can you cheer me up?'"
"Well, if you spend all day watching virtual girls like me, it's no wonder you got rejected. But don't worry! You can be my number one fan instead! I'll be right here for you on stream every single day! ♥"

"My boss chewed me out at work today. I'm so mad."
"Then go punch him at work tomorrow. If you can't wait, you could just go to his house now. But if the Imperial Guard arrests you, it has absolutely nothing to do with me."

"Thanks to 'MiningOverGacha' for the SC! 'Hit pity four times today and lost it every single time. I'm so done spending money.'"
"What a waste, spending money on some random 2D character. You'd be better off sending me a red Super Chat! Who knows, maybe you'll get lucky and pull me instead."

"I feel personally attacked by this streamer. Unfollowed."
"Since you unfollowed me, why're you still here? Mods! Kick him out!"

As Beatrixa "helped" more viewers with their problems, the question marks in chat multiplied. But even though the girl on screen was relentlessly rude, the stream's popularity only continued to climb.

"Alright, that's enough! Any more question marks and I'm gonna start banning people!"
"That's all for our Advice Hotline'! Now, it's time for me to get gaming!"
DiscIP.214001.4:
"Meow-velous mighty Meow-Meow, m-mew-mble..."
"... Ugh, it's a tongue-twister, and it has zero punch."
She flips the page.
"Take aim at all who block our path! Eye of the Demon Lord, open!"
"Now that's more like it! This one's a keeper!"
"Kasimira, what do you think? The perfect opening line for me, right?"
Chaton emerges from a pile of books, shoving a battered, authorless spellbook at her companion.
"Yeah, nice. Great. Go with that one."
Kasimira mumbles a reply, her eyes skimming the page. The magic circle is warped and missing incantations, harmless junk meant to trick kids.
... Then again, it suits the little kitten bouncing around in front of her, happily wrecking the place.
She really is just a child, dragging her all the way out here just to workshop a dramatic entrance.
And she still has to be reminded of the team rules, over and over again.
Kasimira sighs and repeats herself.
"White Cat Squad members never point their weapons at a teammate."
"Chaton, how many times is that?"

Whoops. Busted.
Chaton sullenly lowers her sniper rifle.
Lost in an imaginary firefight, she has aimed at Kasimira without thinking. It wasn't malicious—Kasimira was just her natural focal point.
Was it just a habit?
Maybe.

The little girl had been abandoned so many times she'd lost count.
She stares at the other girl, who looks just as young, her own eyes too dry to squeeze out a single tear for sympathy.
"You don't need to make that face. Prove your worth, and you'll never be abandoned."
A deep female voice speaks from behind the girl.
The sound, paired with a cold, unnerving gaze, sets her on edge.
I don't want to be left behind again. I'll go with anyone ... as long as they take me...
As if reading the hope in her eyes, the voice gives a satisfied command.
"Kasimira, bring her along."

Just like that, a hand takes hers, pulling her forward through the shadows of countless buildings.
"Don't let the captain scare you."
The hand holding her wrist is warm and gentle.
"Those are the White Cat Troupe's rules, not mine."
"I'll hold on to you."

"Chaton, daydreaming in a Monolith will get you killed."
The warning snaps Chaton back to reality just as a Guardian's massive hand slams down toward them.
She takes aim, squeezes the trigger, and recites her brand-new line.
"Eye of the Demon Lord—unleashed!"

"Hmph. Members of the White Cat Squad never look back at explosions."
"Funny how you remember that useless rule perfectly."
Kasimira sighs, signaling Chaton to prepare for the next wave.

"Yes, Captain!"
Chaton strikes a pose from a poster, saluting smartly behind Kasimira's back.
From this angle, that silhouette hasn't changed at all.

I'll hold on to you.
It doesn't matter if you've forgotten that promise.
Because now, even if you let go, I'm strong enough to reach you on my own.
DiscIP.214002.4:
"Clarus Month, Day 21. Rain in the morning, then sun.
I must record this day, lest the Monolith erases it from my memory."

I once devised a meticulous plan to run away.
I set out at dawn, covering my tracks across three rest stops. It was the boldest, most defiant thing I had ever done as Master's student.
But sunset came and Master never descended to drag me back. Had she even noticed I was gone?
So under the cover of darkness, I crept back into the courtyard. Seeing the lamp lit in her room, I relaxed. I stashed my pack in my room and went to bid her goodnight, just like always.
I watched her face, searching for any sign of anger. She seemed normal—until she met my gaze. I knew I was in trouble.
"You're back. Had fun out there?"
Speechless, I could only kneel before her. After what felt like an eternity, she finally set down her teacup.
"Consider today's little trip an exercise in stealth."
"Your skills, however, are abysmal. You could have been found at any moment. You need more practice."
I couldn't believe it. She wasn't scolding me. Then she said something that would stay with me forever.
"But you left without my permission. As punishment, I will also disappear one day, when you least expect it."

I don't remember how I got through that agonizing night. I only remember the crushing fear that Master might actually disappear.
Later, as if in a trance, I stumbled to my desk. A wave of regret poured onto the page as I wrote a long letter of apology.

For seven days, she ignored me. She no longer oversaw my training or cared if I slept in. Terrified, I could do nothing but pen apology after apology.
Then, on the eighth morning, I slid open my door to find her standing there, her long disciplinary ruler in hand, ready to oversee my exercises.
I thought she must have forgiven me.

I held onto that belief, right up until the day she told me she'd been assigned a top-secret mission by our organization.
In the years that followed, Master's missions grew more perilous as her standing in the organization rose. Whenever she was away, I trained relentlessly, no longer the lazy child I once was, hoping I could one day ease her burden.
I expected her to return in a few days, a fortnight at most, just as she always had.
She once told me this courtyard was the only place she trusted, the only place she felt safe. A ninja has no home, but this place was ours.
But this time, she didn't return. I searched the entire courtyard, but found no farewell letter.
I have to believe this is just her punishment—the one she promised me all those years ago.
I am still waiting for her to come back.

—

Before I left, I looked in on her. She was already asleep, assuming I was just off on another mission.
My mind drifted back to that night years ago—a little girl tiptoeing over the wall, trying to act casual as she entered my room. I remembered how her eyes filled with tears after I threatened her.
For seven days after, a letter appeared on my desk each morning. The first was a long, formal apology. The latter ones grew messy, the handwriting of a child fighting off sleep.
The letter on the seventh day was on a damp slip of paper. On it was a single sentence.
"Master, don't go."

The truth is, I had forgiven her long ago.
DiscIP.214005.4:
I discovered a flower.
I say "discovered" because I had never seen one quite like it before.

It grew deep in the third flowerbed from the left, in our agency's backyard.
A professional gardener tended the yard every day, keeping the lawn moist and the flowerbeds perfectly uniform.
I always suspected they used some kind of magic to command the flowers to bloom in unison. I never saw them either.
But this one flower, a dissonant note in a grand symphony, was growing secretly in the shadows.
I figured the gardener had either overlooked it or perhaps planted it themselves. It might be a quiet interlude in his arduous routine.

Now, it has become a small diversion in my daily life. During my lunch break, I walk the stone path in the backyard—a relaxation technique my mentor taught me for sorting through my thoughts and planning my next steps.
On those walks, I used to imagine catching an outlaw scaling the wall, giving me the perfect excuse to challenge him to a duel.
I knew I shouldn't indulge such pointless fantasies. The golden age of duelist advocates was over. I had to become a competent advocate. That was what the Poitou family needed now.
These days, I make a point of stopping by that flowerbed on my walks, just to be sure the flower is still there.
I grew curious about its name, but my knowledge of botany was limited to what I'd learned in school nature class.
Perhaps it was a rare flower, a precious one sprouted from a seed dropped by a passing bird.

That evening, I pulled a heavy botanical encyclopedia from our library.
I flipped through it from cover to cover but found no trace of my flower.
"Could I have discovered a new species?"
I shared the exciting news with my mother, who listened to my description with a puzzled look.
She took the encyclopedia, turned directly to a page, and pointed to a tiny, unremarkable white flower in the corner.
"Darling, is this the one?"
I stared at the picture, comparing it again and again with the flower so vivid in my head. It was, without a doubt, the same one.
I had been in such a hurry that I'd overlooked the entry tucked away in the page's crease. Its description was only a few sentences long.
Still, I couldn't accept it. "But if it's as common as the book says, why have I never seen one before?"
Mother smiled as if answering the simplest question a child could ask.
"Flowers that are too ordinary aren't planted in formal gardens."
"I saw them while vacationing at our country estate. They covered the hillsides. Quite beautiful, in their own way."

Later, I finally saw that scenery for myself.
I had just come through a rather disgraceful episode in my life and set off on a solo journey.
After a rain shower, I was wandering aimlessly through the countryside when I saw it by the roadside—the very flower etched in my memory.
As I knelt for a closer look, a girl's voice called out from behind me.
"Oh! You like Starspots, too?"
I looked up and erupted into a brilliant smile. Her short orange hair shone against the overcast sky, and I remembered the heavy encyclopedia.
"Starspots? I know them as Ground Pimpernels."
"Oh, that's probably the official name. We Trekkers call them Starspots.'Cause they're scattered everywhere like little stars. Their juice makes good herbal medicine, too."
The book never told me that this utterly ordinary flower wasn't entirely useless.
"Thank you. I see."
"No problem! I'm delivering a letter to the next town. We could walk together if you're headed that way."
"I don't really know where I'm going... So, why not? I'll go with you."
DiscIP.214006.4:
Witch.
The very title has a magnetic pull.
Their words went down as sweet as honey, the poison within revealed only as they dissolved.
Mistique is a master of the craft. She would season hot topics with sensationalism and cook up stories that cause an uproar.

"Readers love a thrill, so I give 'em what they want."
That's how Mistique, always grinning, would explain her "magic" to colleagues who came seeking her secrets.
Her colleagues would nod in fervent agreement before bidding her farewell.
They would then hurry off, no doubt, to rack their brains for ways to spice up their own reports, make them more provocative.
But one girl, who looked like a fresh graduate from the witch academy, still clutched her broom clumsily. The headwind caught in her throat as she struggled to ask Mistique a question:
"Are stories like that really what we should be striving for?"
Wearing her usual teasing smile, Mistique adjusted the girl's broom. At least now she wouldn't get blown away.
Then, she gave an answer that satisfied herself completely.
"Well, a witch's gotta make a living."
"After all, you have to pay the bills before you can write what you truly want."

The whisper of a spell crackled on the wind, faint as a silk thread, but nothing escaped a witch's sharp ears.
Mistique waved a hurried goodbye, her broom carving a stylish arc as she dodged an incoming spell.
"Hahahaha, someone's getting desperate, aren't they?"
The target of the attack just cackled, pushing her broom faster and zipping expertly into the depths of an alley—
a natural hiding spot that had helped her evade countless company bounties.
But beyond the gossip, Mistique treasured her other identity: an investigative witch who unearthed the truths this world had buried.

She wove through the streets and alleys with effortless grace, while her summoned spirit playfully released clouds of pink mist to obscure her pursuers' vision.
"You got the guts to do evil, I got the guts to write about it! So there!"
The witch's taunt echoed through the sky.
"Catch me if you can!"
DiscIP.214007.4:
I remember this line from a movie I saw a long time ago:
"Every soul has its light and darkness. Most folks live in the gray between. But I—"
I can't remember the rest. Maybe a Monolith stole it.
But I saw that movie's poster in a shop today, and the line hit me again.

Whenever I needed to clear my head, I'd take a midnight walk through the Ash District, from the harbor to the Waterway.

It was the end of summer, and the cool river breeze always cut through the day's exhaustion.
Frogs croaked, insects buzzed—the only things that never shut up at night.
Now and then, a baby would cry, followed by the frantic pounding of feet on floorboards.
All these sounds bled together, not into chaos, but into a strange, calming harmony.
I never aced literature, but the scene still made me sentimental.
I even started sounding like one of those pretentious lit club kids:
"Maybe this is the heartbeat of the Ash District at night."

But the peace never lasted. A few jerks always had to ruin it.
Scooters whined, voices yelled—so much for a perfect night.

A squad of Imperial Guard knights on scooters skidded to a halt in front of me, flashing their light batons in my eyes.
That's when I remembered my outfit. Good. Saved me the trouble of talking my way out of this.
I dropped my board, whipped out my bat, and busted through their blockade.
It's not that I was scared. I just didn't want the brawl to wake anyone.

I skated through a back alley, leading them straight into a dead end.
Their leader swaggered over, thinking he had me cornered.

"Three-on-one. Nowhere to run!"

The next second, he hit a tripwire. He and his scooter went flying.
"Whoops. Make that three-on-two."

"Don't get cocky! Eat this! —Ugh!"
"My fist hits harder than that spear!"
"Hmph! So what's the score now?"
"It's three-on-three."
"Wasn't askin' you! My math's bad, but I can still count!"

I hefted my bat, glaring at the last knight as he trembled so hard his armor squeaked.
Neuvira and Vollara had just flattened the others.
I still couldn't remember the rest of that line. It didn't matter anymore.

"You must be new. Don't know the rules around here? Let me teach you about them then."
"Listen up. This turf—"
"—is ours!"
DiscIP.214009.4:
Life is a book. You've always believed that. It's just that some people are born deluxe, gilt-edged hardcovers.
And you? You might not even be a book at all, just a simple pamphlet.
But there was a silver lining: you weren't just one pamphlet, you were three.
The three of you were inseparable—sharing bread, roughhousing, and eventually leaving the orphanage, always together.
You never doubted that even if a Monolith erased your memories, you would find each other again and connect instantly.

Sometimes, you found yourself wondering what kind of story your little pamphlet would turn out to be.
A knight's grand adventure? An encyclopedia with all the answers? Or just a simple photo album?
But honestly, did you ever really have a choice?

You worried about the book you'd become, but in truth, you didn't even know what you wanted to be.
Maybe it was easier to just pretend to be a normal book. Unfortunately, "normal" never quite fit you.
Empty wallets, rations running low ... you still had each other, but each other was all you had left.

Let's take another picture. Tuck it into a back page. Remember to smile and save this moment of happiness for the future.
No matter how hard you struggled, you always seemed to end up right back where you started—disappointment is your constant companion.
But for the brief moment the shutter clicked, you were happy. Then the flash faded, and reality came rushing back.

Relax. You're just a pamphlet. If a page gives you trouble, just tear it out and start over.

That means any page has the potential to be your cover. You'll have to choose carefully. Maybe even pick one that's waterproof.
But don't forget, tearing out a page doesn't solve anything. It just leaves you with one less page to write on.
You have to be careful. Once you feel the scratch of your pen against the tabletop, you're running out of paper.
You might have to go back and gather the pages you threw away.

The memories you fought to forget, the pain you buried—you'll have to dig it all up yourself and bind it to the very end of your story.
There's no other way. It's all a part of you. You can't just make it disappear. What you discard in the past will eventually catch up with you—or you with it.
But none of that matters now. It's time to turn the page. As for what the next chapter holds?
Don't worry about it. Just hop aboard the Lucky Oasis and ride into a new chapter. All aboard!
DiscIP.214010.4:
Lady Angie wasn't in her office. Again.
Albedo sighed.
As "that Lady's" most dependable deputy, she was long used to attending high-level meetings in Angie's stead.
Her expression was a constant, stern mask as she strode through offices, corridors, and meeting halls, a small notebook of secrets always in hand.

"Lady Angie, if you don't show your face by next month, people at the headquarters will forget what you look like."
"I have...more important things to attend to."
"...About the last meeting, you..."
"You can handle these tedious matters yourself."
The line went dead.
Albedo sighed again, a sound reserved for when she was alone.
After all, she represented Lady Angie, the embodiment of the Grace Imperium's will. Such an undignified display of weakness could not be seen—

"So, Lady Albedo sighs after all?"
Startled, she turned. The white-haired girl behind her had materialized as silently as a cat.
"Bastelina...if I recall, your intern duties aren't in this area, are they?"
"Ah! As sharp as ever, Lady Albedo! But surely you haven't memorized everyone's schedule? That would be a bit much."
"...No. Lady Angie just gave me specific instructions to keep an eye on...you."
She had nearly slipped into a formal address.

Albedo had handled countless colleagues, but she was completely at a loss with this quirky "intern."
Who was she, really? And why did Lady Angie always adopt a strange, hesitant tone when speaking with her?
How peculiar...

"Don't be so tense all the time. Rest when you can. You wouldn't want to make that certain someone worry, would you?"
Bastelina gave her a light pat on the back, probably because she couldn't reach her shoulder even on her tiptoes.
"Remember to step out for fresh air between tasks, won't you, Lady...Albedo?"
The teasing whisper lingered in her ear.
DiscIP.214011.4:
"Another rainy day."

Donna had recently made a small discovery: Freesia seems to love the rainy season.
She would read by the rain-streaked window, or stare absently at the soft drizzle outside. Whenever Teresa complained about the humidity, she'd look at everyone in confusion and say how pleasant the damp weather felt.
"I'm surprised you like rainy days, Freesia."
"Is it strange?"
"Not strange, just ... different." Donna pointed to her unruly short hair. "The humidity makes my hair frizz up like this—it won't behave, and it's just not a cute look on me."
"Oh, really?" The light-haired girl, untroubled by the dampness, turned to her other friend. "What about you, Teresa? You don't like it either?"
"Um ... I'm not sure." She thought for a moment, trying to explain her mixed feelings. "Water is interesting, and rain is nice, but we can't play outside when it rains."
Donna's hand shot up. "And we can't go buy snacks!"
"But we're all good with water magic... In theory, couldn't we just freeze the rain so it won't get us wet?"
"Is that even possible?!"
"Let's give it a try!"

And so, the girls decided to experiment.
Freesia provided the theory.
"If you guide all the water around you into one spot, you can create a 'dry zone' and walk right through the rain."
Teresa voiced her reluctance.
"My magic isn't that good. Maybe Donna should have a go at it?"
Donna summoned the courage.
"Huh?! Me?"

With everything settled, Donna stood at the doorway and began to channel the raindrops together.
At first, the rain condensed smoothly into an orb, hovering in midair as if caught in a bubble. Donna stepped forward, using the sphere of water as an umbrella.
She wasn't getting wet.
Teresa clapped. "It's actually working! You're amazing, Donna!"
"Of course! I'm Donna of Post Haste! I can do anything!"
Before she could finish, the large sphere of water collapsed, drenching the proud girl from head to toe.
"Uh ... haha, that failed..."
"Quick, get inside! Let's get you dried off!"
"Towels! Give me towels!"


"I guess we still need a sunny day to go out, huh?"
"Shh ... Donna's already fast asleep."
Rain pattered softly from the eaves, as if it, too, were waiting for the sky to clear and paint a rainbow.
DiscIP.214012.4:
United Harvest Headquarters.
Four hours into the meeting, the cold autumn sun was only just creeping past the pillars to reach the conference room doors.
Clang— Clang—
The midday bells rang out, startling a flock of birds into flight and shattering the heavy silence.

The doors swung open from within.
Employees in company uniforms bowed their heads, waiting for the Senator who had presided over the meeting to emerge.
Darcia, who had been seated at his right, was no exception. She removed her hat and lowered herself into a deep, deferential bow.
The old man stopped at the doorway, rapping his cane sharply on the floor.
Darcia lifted her eyes, her gaze instantly locking onto the brooch on his collar.
She had long since burned its design into her memory: a raven of black opal with wings outstretched, its eyes two flawless rubies.
The very symbol of his station as a Senator of United Harvest.

"Darcia. Don't disappoint me."
"I won't."

Shortly after the meeting ended.
Down the hall, a door to an office opened. Inside, Darcia calmly hung her hat on its hook.
She tossed the meeting's resolution—a single sheet of paper—onto her desk as a triumphant smile finally broke across her face.

"It seems you got what you wanted."
A man waiting for her scrambled to pull out her chair, but before he could utter his practiced flattery, Darcia strode past him, plucked a dart from the board on the wall, and sent it flying.
"You know this is merely the first step."

She paid the man no mind. Her gaze was fixed on the map of the Nova Continent dominating the far wall.
"I will provide the sites, the funding, and the materials you need."
"You will deliver results. Fast. Before the Senate elections."
The dart sailed in a perfect arc and pierced the map's lower-left corner, the dead center on Philae, the city of her new appointment.
DiscIP.214013.4:
Where does the sea truly end? What lies beyond the horizon?
If we could reach that distant line where the water meets the sky, what wonders would we find?
The very thought sends a thrill through you. To sail that far, to conquer the sea... that would be...

Thud!
"Oww... that hurts..."
"Caught you dozing off again huh?"
Horizon rubs her forehead and opens her eyes to find Willow standing over her, clutching a folder.
"Ahaha... where were we?"
"Your shipbuilding budget..."
Leafia whispers from beside her.
"Oh, right, the budget! I saw the proposal. We already secured the crucial power components from the Monolith. All we need is a little bit of funding, and we'll have our ship ready for expedition!"
Horizon shoots a hopeful glance at Willow.
"What do you think?"
Willow scans the file, then looks up at her with a smile.
"There is absolutely no precedent for a plan like this. And this blueprint—you drew it yourself, didn't you?"
"Er..."
"Frankly, a ship built from these designs would sink before it even left the harbor."
"How can you say that? We'll never know unless we try!"
"And what's this 'Voyage Supplies Procurement' list? You're shopping for a trip when we don't even have a ship?"
"We'll have a ship soon enough! We just need the funds and the crew. Besides, we've already got a navigator. We gotta put her skills to use, right, Leafia?"
"Oh... huh? Me?"
"If you went sweet-talk investors with Kinsa, maybe the Trekker Association could actually scrape together enough money for your grand vessel."
"Really?"

...Maybe?
Faced with Horizon's raw, unwavering passion, even Willow feels her own certainty waver.
They say a dreamer's eyes hold nothing but freedom and a sea of stars. It looks to be true.
Horizon's eyes shine, filled with an intense longing for her dream.
An idealist's conviction always brings hope, courage, and a bit of luck to a journey where tomorrow is never guaranteed.

"Alright, I get it. While most of your proposal is irrational, we can discuss the parts that are actually feasible."
"But isn't the whole thing worth a shot?"
"Keep pouting like that and it'll never pass the Association vote, you know."
"That's cold—"
"However, if we adjust it like this..."

Even if we can't set sail now, she thinks, I have to protect this spark of hope until the day we finally can.
DiscIP.214014.4:
"So much fruit over here! Let me just give a little puff of magic and bring them down."
"I'll catch... Whoa, my basket's full already! Hehe, we're going to eat so well."
"I-I'm stuck..."
"Fuyuka, hold still! Don't move too much, you'll break the branch..."
(Whimpers)
"It's okay, just jump. I've got you."

Listening to her friends chattering, a quiet smile graced Nazuna's lips.
"You keep picking. I'm just gonna rest over here for a bit."
"Besides, filling my stomach is its own kind of rest..."
Her eyes fixed on a plump fruit. She couldn't help but swallow as her hand slowly reached out.

Nazuna took a huge bite, the sweet juice from the soft pulp bursting over her tongue.
"Wow, so sweet!"
Her eyes crinkled with delight as she swung her legs, her heart feeling lighter by the second.
"Here, you have a bite too."
Nazuna set the fruit in the small basket beside her, next to the plushie she always kept close.
"Hehe, what do you think? Sweet, right?"

"Hey, Nazuna! You're eating already?"
"Well, if someone's picking, someone's gotta eat, right? We can't let good fruit go to waste."
"I can't believe that's your excuse..."
"Alright, alright, no fighting. We've picked more than enough, so we can leave some for any Trekkers who pass by. C'mon, everyone, get down from the trees so we can eat together!"

It was an ordinary day.
A season for harvest, a season for friendship.
But sweeter than the fruit was the quality time spent with friends.
DiscIP.214017.4:
