"Wow, it's so pretty... Is this a firework?"
"Yes. Hold it like this, and you can watch it burn with all its might."
Filled with curiosity, the girl carefully lit the gift.

The moment it ignited, a sputtering flame flickered to life at its tip.
It was a nascent power, like a flower bud just before it blooms.

With a pop and a crackle, the sparks flared brilliantly.
The burst of light was like a windflower in spring, or a novice fearlessly pressing onward toward their dream.

Sparks began to shoot and cascade, their bright yellow melting into orange, then scarlet.
This shower of sparks was like the prime of every Trekker's journey, as stern and full as pine needles in autumn.

The sparks slowly dimmed and vanished into the darkness. The light lost its upward force, scattering and withering until only faint embers lingered in the smoke, then disappeared without a trace.
It reminded the girl of an autumn chrysanthemum.
After the most beautiful colors fade, all that remains is to wither. But the petals that fall to the earth nourish the next life.

Ignition, bloom, brilliance, and decay—in the space of a single breath, the firework raced through its intense life cycle.
Because life is fleeting, it must burn desperately to leave something behind.
A Trekker's life is a grand adventure just like that.

Her silky hair streamed in the breeze, shimmering in the light. Each firework that blossomed at her fingertips seemed to set the night sky ablaze.
In the distance, the Monolith stood watch, joining the fireworks to light up a small world of two.
One after another...
With a smile on her face, she would let out a small cheer now and then before falling quiet again, watching the sparks ignite and die, over and over.

As the last sparkler burned out, the girl reluctantly rose to her feet.
"Was that good?"
"Yes. Thank you, Master..."
A shy smile touched her lips.
"You're welcome."

"When we get the chance, we should set off fireworks with everyone."
"R-Really...?"
The girl clenched her fists, her eyes shining with hope.
"Of course. We can even find bigger ones that last longer and burst into different shapes in the sky. But for now, let's focus on the adventure right in front of us."
"Yes, Master!"
DiscIP.214018.4:
Firenze arrived early.
She was perhaps a little too early. As she waited, condensation had already misted over her glass.
Firenze wasn't in a hurry, though. She studied a small potted plant on the table, its leaves thriving—a stark contrast to the ones on her desk that she periodically killed off.
For a company executive whose time was measured in millions of Dorra, staring into space like this was an utter waste.

"Been waiting long?"
The woman she was waiting for finally slid into the seat across from her. Nyx looked like she'd been ravaged by work for three days straight.

"Mhm. So long the flowers have withered."
"It can't be that bad. I was ... what, three minutes late?"
"Two minutes and forty-six seconds, to be precise. Still, I'm pleasantly surprised. I expected the queen of tardiness to show up twenty minutes later."
Nyx, the Queen of Tardiness herself, gauged the accusation in Firenze's tone. Finding no real sting behind the words, she took the offered menu without a hint of guilt.

"Take your time. Drink first? Tea, or lemon juice like me?"
"Lemon juice... Your palate for commoner tastes has certainly expanded since our academy days."
"I heard a lot of Trekkers drink it to stay sharp. I tried it once, and that sour kick is surprisingly effective."
"I'll have tea, thank you."
Nyx immediately flagged down a server for a tea. A steaming cup was delivered to their table moments later.

"The review meeting is next week. Did you ask me here to go over my report beforehand?"
Once all the desserts were served, they finally got down to business.
"I've always had faith in your reports. It's those old foxes at United Harvest I'm worried about. They'll attack you on the details, hoping you'll stumble into one of their traps."
"My, my. Sounds like they're still circling."
"This is a rare opportunity. And going forward ... we face them together."

"After what happened, I never thought I'd get another invitation from you."
Nyx confessed with a sigh. By unspoken agreement, they changed the subject—but that is another story.
DiscIP.214019.4:
The day had arrived.
Chaton carefully wiped down the pistol in her hands.
It was sleek and light. If she listened closely, she could hear the faint rattle of its inner workings.
Normally, no one in the White Cat Squad would trust their life to such a shoddy piece of gear.
This time, however, Chaton considered it her ace in the hole.
It was, after all, just a toy for her upcoming shooting game against Kasimira.

"Perfect. A nice, smooth draw."
Satisfied, Chaton raised the gun and aimed at the heart on the arcade screen.
All that was left was to pick the perfect line for the occasion from her mental copy of the Divine Cat Declaration of War.
"The crimson moon hangs high, the gates of blood swing open, and the defeated shall be cast into an abyss of curses—"
"Let this one shot decide it all, Kasim—Gah!"
Before she could finish, the heart on the screen lit up—a direct hit.
The point hadn't gone to the monologuing Chaton, but to the other contestant standing right behind her.
"You take so long to wind up. An opponent will take that opening every time, Chaton."
"But when I'm here, I can cover for you, just like that."
That was Kasimira, Chaton's captain.

"But we're opponents right now," Chaton shot back, slamming the machine's reset button. "That one didn't count. Let's go again."
"Play as many times as you want. I'm still gonna win."
"That's not what my cat-fortune said! She ate the food I gave her, so ... victory will be mine!"
"So that's why you challenged me today." Kasimira grabbed the other light gun, adjusted her stance, and gave Chaton a nod to begin.

The first round.
The second.
...
All the way to the thirty-seventh.
The score was thirteen to fourteen. Just one more point and Chaton would finally claim her first victory.
One more point ... Chaton's breath hitched.
Damn it, my trigger finger slipped! My form is off.
Bang! A bright red X flashed over the heart. The score didn't change.

"You hesitated at the last second, Chaton."
Fifteen to fourteen. Kasimira had won again. "Too bad. You were only one shot away."
"You almost got me. Not bad at all."

"So close! I'm so hyped right now! I'm on a roll! Again! One more round!"
Kasimira ruffled Chaton's hair, reining in her frantic energy.
"Easy now. That's enough for today. It's time to get ready for our next commission."
DiscIP.214020.4:
"Starting today, I'm keeping the Post Haste Chronicles!"
Donna opens a brand-new notebook and carefully smooths the first page.
"Chronicles...? What's that?" Teresa asks, peeking over her shoulder.
"You know, for writing down all the big things that happen at Post Haste. Like, 'Landed a huge job, bought a new bike,' or somethin'."
"That's a good idea. What brought this on?" Freesia asks, her curiosity piqued.
"I was delivering a letter to the corner bookstore yesterday, and the owner insisted I take this. Said it was a new model and we could use it for our ledgers." Donna hands the notebook to Freesia. "Look, isn't it pretty?"
"It is. The paper's so smooth, and the cover's ornate."
"Exactly! It's too nice for just bookkeeping. It's gotta be for something more meaningful."
Brimming with confidence, Donna picked up her pen and wrote "Property of Post Haste" on the title page.
"I can't wait to see what our first big event will be!"

Day 1: Nothing happened.
Day 2: Nothing happened.
Day 3: Still nothing happened.

By afternoon, Donna sits at her desk, racking her brain—her initial excitement has dwindled.
"Teresa, Freesia, are you sure nothing special's happened these past few days?"
"I saw a super big rabbit when I was on a delivery yesterday!"
"I found an old coin, but I couldn't find the owner, so I put it back."
"No, no, think harder!"
"I ... I tripped yesterday and almost hit my head..."
"I ... ran into Kui on my way back from delivering papers and played hopscotch with her."
"... You two!" Donna's head throbs in pain. "Teresa, no wonder you were limping last night! And you told me you were just waddling like a duck."
"And you, Freesia! You were gone so long I was worried you'd gotten into trouble."
Seeing them both hanging their heads apologetically, Donna's frustration melts away. "Never mind. I guess there really isn't anything to write about."
"You can write about anything, you know. Even the little things," Freesia says, motioning for Teresa to join them. They settle on either side of Donna. "As long as you write it down, when you look back on it, you'll remember how you felt."
"Like how passing a bakery reminds me of the taste of a cake I once had?" Teresa yawns, stretching her arms across the table. "We haven't had cake in forever..."

As the afternoon sun fills the room, Donna snaps the notebook shut, her mind made up.
"Let's go. We're getting cake. And when we're back, I'll write it all down—that'll be our very own, one-of-a-kind big event!"
"The color, the shape, the taste... There's so much to write about."
"Great! I'll go pump up the bike tires. We can check on Auntie Helen on the way."
"Hooray! I want a cherry cake!"

The door clicks shut. On the desk, the notebook gleams.
DiscIP.214021.4:
Wandering birds breed in the north, then fly south for the winter.
The freezing north is a struggle. The warm south, a comfort.
But even birds of a feather do not all take the same path.

Those born in the north chase the warmth south.
Those born in the south flee the heat for the north.
The northern birds think they've found a warm paradise, but in truth, they've never left the world they know.
In the heart of winter or summer, the two flocks will likely never meet.
Yet in the fleeting seasons of spring and autumn, their separate journeys converge.

A bond can connect you, but it cannot bind your fates together.
When lives are so different, why cherish a meeting destined to end?
Had nothing happened, had you never met, you would have remained passers-by in each other's life.

"Do you really believe that?"

The voice cut through time and space, echoing in the silent night.
Exhausted from their game, Nazuka lay back in the meadow, watching a giddy Nazuna chase a shrieking Fuyuka with handfuls of water. Nearby, Kaede sat hugging her knees, a fond smile on her face.
"It's not often we get to just mess around like this, is it?"
"Yeah. There's always some commission... It feels good to unwind."
"So, you still haven't answered my question. Do you really believe all that, Nazuka?"
"I..." She paused. "What I think ... doesn't matter anymore."

Under the stars, the wandering birds rested by the lake. A subtle bond held them together, yet each carried their own unspoken burdens.

"Sooner or later, we'll all go our separate ways. I just hope we each get to live out our dreams. I think that would be enough."
After a long silence, Kaede gently stroked Nazuka's hair and sighed.
"Is that really enough?"
Just then, a triumphant Nazuna marched over, dragging a soaked Fuyuka with her.
"Hey, this isn't over! Nobody stops playing splash war with me until I say so!"
She and Kaede shared a look.
"Nazuna, have you forgotten? I know magic."
"Whaaa?! Hey, no cheating! Kaede, do something about her!"
"Hehe..."

Whether from north or south, every wandering bird feels the boundless freedom and deep loneliness of the long journey.
They soar over the vast land, watching the world glitter and fade below. Dawn's first light and dusk's last glow take turns bathing their wings.
Beneath the endless sky, their lives seem at once so small and yet so magnificent.

But the day of parting always comes.
The wandering birds fly on, each to their own path, carrying memories of the past and hopes for the future into every new season.
DiscIP.214022.4:
It's been days since Amber last visited the black kitten.
Stretched out on the rooftop, watching clouds drift by, basking in sunlight, the kitten begins to feel a bit bored.
"Meow—"
It leaps down from the roof and strolls toward the Trekker Camp.

...

In the Lucky Oasis, the New Star Guild huddles around a projector, exchanging puzzled looks.
A newly wish-granted Artifact lying dormant? That's new.
"Have we run out of Grace?"
"Can't be. We just charged the Soul Stone before leaving, and ... we've skipped several fights. Should have plenty left."

Moments later.
"I've heard repairs cost an arm and a leg in the Cities ... wanna give it one more shot?"
"How?"
"According to 'Guide To Living In Emor,' faulty artifacts just need a good whack at the two-thirds mark from the top..."

"BANG!"
The screen stutters to life, displaying a psychedelic disc pattern.
"Did ... that actually work?"
Noya stays frozen in place, hand still hovering above the projector, looking questioningly at the others.
"Since the projector works now ... does this mean commission complete?"
 
"Even though it's a bit late to turn this in now..."
"So what now?"
"Maybe test the projector first... Wait, was this film reel here before?"
 
Underneath the projector lies a mysterious film reel—its packaging worn, its lettering faded beyond recognition.
"Drinks coming right up!"
"I'm on snack duty!"
Left alone, Amber eyes the odd reel with suspicion but finally feeds it into the projector.

...

The setting sun withdraws its light from the land as darkness creeps in.
The black kitten observes the silhouette of the campsite ahead, catching a familiar scent in the air that confirms Amber's presence.
Paws silent, steps light, it moves toward the scent.

...

"Ugh, this film sucks. What's even going on?"
"Hey ... guys? Mind me squeezing in? I'm feeling chilly all of a sudden."
"Sure... Hold on. Why's the screen glitching again?"
Darkness has claimed the night, and the RV is dim, broken only by the projector's ghostly light.
The film's not just boring... It's strange and eerie. The screen stutters with distorted static, tangled in monochrome noise.
No score, only the faint whisper of wind.
The reel's label is illegible now, discouraging them from seeking further information.

...

"Scrrtch—"
The black kitten attempts to push open the door of the Oasis, but finds it unbudging.
So it sets out to explore other possible entries.

...

Just as the black kitten vanishes into the shadows, Noya flings the door open.
"No one's out there! Iris, are you sure you're not hearing things?" She shouts to her companions glued to the screen.

...

"Achoo! Strange... Something's not quite right."
Noya sneezes and worms her way deeper into the couch.
 
"Hey, easy there! You're going to spill the popcorn!"
Iris protests half-heartedly, scooting closer to the other two herself.
 
"Thud. Thud. Thud. Thud."
A sound echoes from above their heads.
 
"I swear I can hear footsteps up there..."
Amber mutters, wrapping an arm around Noya. Something feels off, but she can't pinpoint what.
 
"I heard them too."
"Should we check outside again?"
"Guys ... look at the well on the screen... Something's ... something's barging out!"
 
...
 
Finally, the black kitten finds its way in—through the half-open sunroof.
It stretches gracefully before sliding through the opening.
Its landing perfectly timed with the film's most terrifying moment, directly before the trio...
 
"AHHHHHHH!"
"MEOWWWWW!"
 
Their combined screams shatter the night's peaceful silence.
DiscIP.214023.4:
Lately ... her skateboard's bearings feel rusty, the wheels turning with an unpleasant drag.
Her baseball bat no longer feels like an extension of her arm, its swing producing a dull thud like shaking out an old sack.
Minova feels weary, but she can't figure out why.
Is school getting tougher?
Hardly. She's still confident about securing the Platinum Academy scholarship.
Is Ashwind in trouble?
But it hasn't fought rival gangs in ages—
their days are spent playing the same old cat-and-mouse game with the Imperial Knight.
Now that she thinks about it, Minova realizes she hasn't seen Neuvira or Vollara around.
No troubles are in sight and studies are well in hand, yet exhaustion clings to her like a shadow.
Somehow, the daily grind has lost its charm.

"You really think this'll cheer up the cap?"
"Come on, she's barely older than us. Bet deep down, she must want to have some fun too."
Neuvira and Vollara return to the clan, carrying a crate of fresh spray cans.

"Time for some fun, cap!"
"I dunno..."
"No excuses! Check this out..."
"Psshh—"
A vibrant red blooms before Minova.
"Sun's out, fun's out."

Yielding to their persistence, Minova finds herself at the docks she hasn't visited in ages.
The realization hits her—when was the last time she properly enjoyed the fresh air out here?
"Heads up, cap!"
Instinctively, Minova swings her bat. Syougi Ketsu feels alive in her hands again. As the ball soars,
something inside her just clicks back into place.

The crisp sound of the hit draws the attention of the girls mid-spray.
"Haven't seen cap grin like that in forever."
"For real. She's actually acting her age for once!"
"Hey, you've got paint on your face."
"Whatever. Better than getting roughed up in a fight. So ... decided what to paint?"
Neuvira raises her spray can again.
"Hmm ... how about a rainbow?"
DiscIP.214026.4:
"Am I permitted to depart now?"
"Not yet, Chitose."
"Understood."

A peaceful pond lies beneath a modest waterfall that tumbles down from the rocky walls above, its waters flowing endlessly into the distance.
Apart from the manor, this is the place Chitose visits most often—
for today, as always, her training focuses on water.
Chitose can't understand it. Her blade can effortlessly cuts through grass, leaves, mud, trees ... even massive rocks.
But how does one cut water?
Every time her sword touches water, the water simply shape-shift to cater to the blade.
Lift the blade, and droplets climb the tip; dop the blade, and droplets descend in sync.
How can one truly cut water?
Hold the blade horizontally in its depths? The water simply wraps around the steel, flowing above and below. It remains whole and free—where each drop is both nothing and everything.
Maybe create waves instead? The water dances, rolls, and twirls, but unlike stone or earth, it never truly breaks into distinct pieces.
Too many questions cloud Chitose's mind.
There by the flowing stream and still pond, she loses herself in an endless cycle: sword practice, meditation, more practice, deeper contemplation...
until weariness takes hold.
On her 200th swing today, Chitose fails to notice the droplets beneath her feet.
"—!?"
She loses her footing and tumbles into the pond.

Not wishing to endure the cold and suffocating embrace of the stream a second more, she quickly stands up. The water, thankfully, only reaches her knees. The waterfall crashes down just above where she stands,
leaving Chitose's once-neat hair in disarray.

"I see now."
She remains still as she lets herself feel the rhythmic surge of the water flowing around her.

She finally discovers why she couldn't grasp it before—she had been too preoccupied with her sword, never properly feeling the water in her hands or on her body.
Now, she has become one with the flow.

Drawing a deep breath, she raises her sword again.
The water's movement around her becomes gentler,
separating from her fingers and sword's edge.

The falling water seems to be tenderly lifted and guided,
following her sword's movement to trace a circle in the air—
could this ... be considered cutting water?
While unsure of the answer, Chitose experiences her first taste of genuine confidence.
"Water, what a marvelous thing."

"May I ... finally set forth now?"
"Not yet, Chitose."
A brief pause follows, "You're still too hasty, Chitose."

"Before you go ... you should at least wring out those clothes and dry yourself properly..."
DiscIP.214027.4:
"What on earth are you drawing?"
 
More than once have onlookers pointed at Chixia's talismans with skepticism and contempt in their eyes.
Their reactions were understandable. The world knows what a talisman should look like: pristine white paper marked with black ink, bearing either scriptures, perfectly rendered guardian beasts, or simple words of blessing. These are what people trust, what they believe in.
But Chixia? She walks a different path.
When she wields her brush, no one can predict what follows that first stroke.
Unrecognizable animals, twisted characters, cryptic symbols, sometimes just pure blackness.
Such is her way, different from all others, and the world answers her uniqueness with thorns of judgment.
"Will this even work?"
"Is this some kind of joke?"
"Are you trying to fool me!?"
Chixia remains unmoved by doubts, her brush strokes falling beyond common sense yet within the laws of her own world—a realm visible only to her eyes. That is why no doubt could shake her. She holds absolute faith in her craft.
"If it doesn't work, come back to me. I'll refund you by the triple,"
she always says, her face adorned with ink like a calico cat, offering no further explanation.

With each passing day, more people discover the protective power of her artwork, and her seemingly random doodles prove to be surprisingly trustworthy talismans.
The skeptical voices begin to falter, and although some still raise eyebrows at her artistic process, the comments have become more diverse: some offer explanations, others give encouragement, and a few even interpret her oddly-drawn chickens as new spiritual guardians of the Xuan Shi sect.
With ink smudges on her face resembling that of a calico cat's patterns, Chixia scribbles across vast sheets of paper. The quarrels of others remain beyond her comprehension—and she wants to keep it that way.
The day she earned her title as a Xuan Shi, her master placed this brush in her hands. Three teachings were carved into her memory that day:
Never belittle your imagination;
Never chain yourself to mortal conventions;
Never fear to create.

She waves her brush in elaborate patterns, finding solace in her talismans as she confronts the supernatural horrors invisible to common folk.
This is a battle fought in strokes, by a Xuan Shi alone.
DiscIP.214028.4:
"Close your eyes."
"Steady your breathing."
"Imagine yourself standing in a room. Feel its warmth, its silence. Here, you're safe from any interruption."
"Now... what do you see?"
The young girl diligently follows her master's guidance, yet her mind remains completely blank.
She can't tell the truth, fearing it would reveal her inadequate progress and lead to punishment.
As silence stretches uncomfortably between them, she knows she must say something.
"I see... flowers everywhere. I'm in a garden."
"A garden? What flowers grow there? Are they in full bloom or have they withered?"
"Um..."
Her little lie crumbles under such precise questioning. Nanoha keeps her eyes tightly shut, waiting for her master's criticism.
"The heart of spiritual training lies in honest self-reflection. Deceiving yourself will lead you nowhere."
"As part of the Tanikaze, we must face harsh realities. Without the ability to create a mental haven from this world, you'll find the coming days unbearable."
"This differs from your usual training—take your time with it."
While the words' true meaning remains beyond Nanoha's grasp, she notices something surprising—her master's voice carries no hint of reprimand.
"But tell me, this 'garden' you spoke of—is it like the one in our courtyard?"
"Yes."
In her panic, her mind reaches instinctively for that tiny, desolate flower bed. Where sunflowers once reached for the sky, only withered stalks and fragile leaves remain.
She often loses herself staring at the dried seeds in the flower heads, imagining how magnificent the sunflowers must have been in full bloom.

As dusk settles on the following day, Nanoha returns to find the garden soil upturned, the broken sunflowers nowhere to be seen.
Her heart skips a beat as she hears her master's faint voice coming from behind,
"Starting today, you shall take care of the flower bed—watering, tending to seedlings, all of it."
That summer, she finally sees it—a sea of flowers in full bloom.
The once-barren earth is now awash with newborn gold. She has built her own secluded world, soft and steadfast as the soil itself.

Years later, when Nanoha leaves the courtyard, she carefully seals away every fragment of her past.

It isn't until the organization sends her to care for an injured senior that she steps back into this long-forgotten courtyard of memories.
The senior, who once had brief dealings with her master, sighs,
"This garden is truly lovely. I visited a handful of times ... back when you were still a little one."
"I even suggested to your master that the place could use some flowers. And yet, it remains unchanged."
Her breath catches, "...We grew sunflowers once."
"That can't be right. Your master said the organization prohibited any changes to the courtyard—it needed to look abandoned. I've been visiting nearly every year, and I've never once seen sunflowers."

In the golden-lit room, Nanoha runs through the possibilities again and again.
Climbing the Monolith makes one forget.
But when did those memories of sunflowers first take root in her mind?
Are they real? Or fabricated?
Could they be self-created, nothing but an ethereal dream?
She wishes to believe the senior is the one with missing memories, that everything really happened.
But as she was taught long ago, she cannot deceive herself. The only person who could prove the truth—who taught her to dig, to plant, to water—has disappeared.
Only by finding her can all secrets be revealed.
She must find her.

She rises and steps into the sunlight.
The next journey might have no end.
DiscIP.214030.4:
It's a regular afternoon... the sun's shining, the trees are dancing in the soft breeze—just a peaceful day like any other.
As usual, Willow is buried in piles of work at her desk. Today, though, while her pen never stops, her mind wanders as she looks at the cold tea on her desk.
She has a feeling that someone is about to visit.
Right on cue, cicadas begin buzzing outside, mixed with some strange noises. A shadow suddenly appears at the open window, and a voice reaches her ears before the speaker comes into view.
"Hello there, Lady Willow. What are you up to today?"
Willow meets Laru's gaze—the girl who just climbed through her window—and offers a practiced smile,
"Just work. Like always, Lady Laru."
Sunlight halos the girl skipping her work as she waves a bag of pastries with a cheerful smile.
"I brought tea snacks! Break time."
 
Willow loves to tease that if Laru ever comes through the main door, it would mean either she's caused some monumental trouble, or there's been a complete breakdown between the Trekker Association and the Grace Imperium.
Laru never fails to protest with mock solemnity.
"Hello? I'm skipping work here! What kind of slacker would waltz through the main entrance? That's asking to be caught! And isn't all this sneaking around what makes playing hooky so much fun?"
Willow can only respond with an indulgent smile, masking a tiny trace of envy at such carefree behavior.
In return for the consistent afternoon tea deliveries, the window in Willow's office remains faithfully open for Laru, come rain or shine.
 
"So, what's the french fry flavor of the day?"
Willow puts her pen aside and tidies up the desk scattered with documents, creating space for their teatime ritual.
With a slight pout, Laru starts laying out the treats one by one.
"Didn't you say you were tired of fries last time? There's this new bakery that just opened around the corner, so I brought some donuts and bread instead."
"Oh my, you actually remember what I said?"
She stretches, ready to move about.
"Let me fetch some water then—what kind of tea would Lady Laru prefer today?"
"Mmm... I'm in the mood for something that tastes like afternoon sunshine, hehe."
DiscIP.214031.3: The Clash of Blade and Axe
DiscIP.214031.4:
She meets her for the first time on just another rainy afternoon.
Chitose goes through her morning routine—smoothing out the futon, rolling it tight, lining up her three beloved katanas with ceremonial precision.
Her self-training journey follows no set path; as she wanders freely each day, for a blade cannot be honed on but a single stone.
This time though, she stays longer than usual, tempted by the delicious onigiris from the shop below her lodgings.
Yet now, the time has come for her departure.

She lifts her travel pack and pushes open the door, only to hear angry shouts erupting from below,
"There's something wrong with your onigiris! My stomach's hurting. You'll pay for this!"
"Explain yourself, or I'm not leaving!"
A crowd gathers before the shop, buzzing with excitement like flies drawn to carrion.
Such sights make Chitose's blood boil.
If she were stronger, she could expose these demons hiding behind human faces and become the sword of justice itself.
But today, it seems her farewell onigiri will remain a wish ungranted.

"Please calm down. Shouting like this won't get us anywhere. Why don't you tell me what's really going on?"
Chitose watches from upstairs as a girl with blue hair and black robes catches everyone's attention. The crowd parts like flowing water, all eyes suspicious of this uninvited stranger.
"That uniform... She's an advocate?""The shop owner's screwed. They're going to pay dearly for this."
Chitose realizes this isn't a title that commands respect. An advocate ... but who does she advocate for?
"... Right, got it."
"You purchased a few onigiris three days ago and felt unwell after eating them last night."
"May I ask if you took any preservation measures after bringing them home?"
Her logic cuts through the argument like a finely honed sword.
"Given the recent heat, food left at room temperature easily spoils. To be precise, you cannot definitively prove the shop is at fault. Maybe just be more careful next time."

The crowd scatters as rain begins to fall. Still leaning against the railing, Chitose feels electric anticipation coursing through her: a desire to test her mettle against this advocate.
Deep within, she knows that crossing swords with this one would hone her own edge.
Yet the other bears no arms, and for a "blade" to challenge such would be both unjust and uncouth.
As she suppresses the urge to issue a challenge, the advocate seems to sense her presence, lifting her gaze to meet Chitose's directly.
Even through the curtain of rain, those crimson eyes burn like a freshly tempered katana—fierce and ardent.


Two years later, Chitose's journey of self-training reaches a temporary pause.
She settles in an abandoned waystation, rarely visited by people, and names it the "Pavilion of Rain's Whispers."
This morning, as she senses the coming rain in the air, she ponders ways to welcome wandering Trekkers.
As predicted, the afternoon unleashes a tempest. Howling winds and stinging debris threaten to tear the roof off.
Through the gloom, a figure struggles against the wind and rain.
"Might you seek shelter beneath this humble roof?"
Wielding her slender tachi, Chitose performs her distinctive welcome ritual, one that typically sends visitors fleeing in terror.
Yet this time, a battle-axe clashes against her blade with a deafening shriek.
"I'll have to pass. My journey awaits. Thank you for the gesture."
In the gleaming reflection of crossed blades, a pair of crimson eyes stares back.
Ecstasy courses through her veins as she tightens her grip, instantly entering the state of Psyche. This encounter shall mend previous regrets.

Perhaps after their clash, her guest will accept her hospitality at the pavilion and taste one of her carefully crafted onigiris.
DiscIP.214032.4:
"Open up—!"
"Coming!"
Mistique bursts through the doorway before Ophir even has a chance to make way.
"Close it—!"
"Done— Hold on, Misti! Since when did I become your personal doorkeeper?"

This is a hidden workshop where witches secretly craft the most explosive news—the most dreaded, unfiltered, and spicy source of the juiciest scandals about Nova's major companies, corrupt officials of city guilds, decadent priests of the Grace Imperium, and flashy gang bosses!
The age of Scarlet Sights Media's reporting has long since passed!
It's common knowledge that those cheap papers are just ad-filled mouthpieces for their wealthy backers!

"Honestly, they should stop cramming news between ads and sponsored content. It's so awkward!"
"My, Misti, your criticism is as sharp as ever!" Ophir says with a warm smile, serving tea to her breathless visitor. "Don't tell me you got rejected again?"
Mistique tosses a stack of manuscripts at Ophir with visible frustration.
"See? I told you it was all for nothing—"
"Is this ... what you mentioned last week...?"
"At their mere word—snap! Two weeks of undercover work, a whole afternoon in the library, all-night writing, plus a dozen photos—all wasted!"
"Aww, poor Misti!"
"Stop patting my head! Aren't you mad about being pushed around like this too?"
"I'm just an anchor, dear. I only read from the script!"
"That's why I envy you! All you need is a pretty face, a nice voice, and the confidence to hold a microphone!"
"Hehe, Misti, you really have it rough. That's why I'm here to be your doorkeeper!"

Mistique is still technically "licensed," but the higher-ups at Scarlet Sights Media have her on their watch list—triple-checking every story she files. They couldn't care less about angry employees, but sponsors? It's a different story entirely. That's just how things work, not just at Scarlet Sights Media, but throughout all of Flavio.
Thus, she comes up with her own idea for distributing news—a shabby little office, boldly named the "Dream Factory of Truth."

"But, Misti ... you realize you'll be writing everything yourself, right?"
"I'm aware!"
"And take all the photos yourself, gather all the research materials on your own."
"Fully aware!"
"Even find your own paper and ink?"
"Of course I know all that!"
"But seriously, Misti—"
Ophir leans in close to Mistique, who's frantically sorting through manuscript papers.
"What's the point of doing all this?"

Mistique halts her movements, her upward gaze filled with both reproach and doubt.
"But I'm a witch, aren't I?! If I lack even this much determination—"
"No profit, a bounty on your head, and furthermore..."

The one posing the question draws her lovely face nearer to the witch, her gaze intense and direct.
"Perhaps no one will ever know it was you. No one will thank you for it. Do you understand that?"
"Ugh—"
Uncertainty flickers through the witch's eyes.
"... Perhaps I ... haven't thought this through..."

"Oh dear." Ophir takes a step back, shaking her head, "Such weak determination just won't cut it, my dear Misti."

"Well then, care to share why you dragged me all this way? Surely you need me to be more than just a doorkeeper?"
With that, she rolls up the sleeves of her elegant shirt,
"Time to get to work. Today's truths won't process themselves!"
DiscIP.214033.4:
An intriguing patient visits the clinic today.
Coronis pulls out her medical records, marking a peculiar symbol in the name column.
"An Inquisitor from the Grace Imperium's ... Dusk Arbiter. Hehe."
 
"Doctor, I haven't been feeling well lately."
In the examination room, the patient, dressed in cleric's robes, pants faintly, her face contorted in pain.
"My lungs ... no, my heart. It hurts, like a dull ache."
Coronis' nerves twitch as she observes the woman clutching her right chest—
This blatant lie reveals the "patient" has hidden intentions.
 
"Doctor, why stare at my right arm instead of starting the checkup?"
The patient impatiently jumps to another topic.
"Does my armband intrigue you? Tell me, doctor, does this emblem awaken something sentimental in you?"
"Typically, I prescribe silencing potions to chatty patients."
Coronis smiles and picks up a vial that glows purple. In an instant, it appears in the patient's grasp.
"Is it bitter? Does it hurt? Only one way to find out."
The patient's eyes gleam with manic curiosity, her lips curving into the same smile as Coronis.'

The portion slides down her throat and into her belly, leaving a trail of searing heat in its wake.
Gerie savors the precise measure of pain, her eyes narrowing in pleasure at the soothing sensation.
She attempts to speak, but is taken aback by how quickly the portion begins its work.
"Eeh ... ugh, mmph—!" A string of breathy sounds escapes her lips, perhaps even she herself unsure of what she meant to say.
"—Mmph!"
Gerie gives the doctor a thumbs up—she actually wants to say that this works even better than what she uses in the interrogation room, and...
How could they let someone this talented ... go so easily?

"Wham—" Cast out into the street, Gerie shakes the dust from her robes.
She picks up the shovel she had left by the clinic's entrance.
While she only meant to greet this fascinating "Reaper Doctor" today, the visit proves unexpectedly rewarding: indeed, Gerie has caught the scent of secrets—
the fragrance of one who dances with "Death."
DiscIP.214036.4:
"An angel...? Is it time...?"
"No, dear one. Look closer—these are merely a Seeker's robes. It's only me."
"Forgive me, sister... Everything's getting so blurry..."
"It's my fault for not listening to the Luminar. I stayed up reading comics, and totally ruined my eyes..."
Medical artifacts fill the room with their numbing drone.
The girl on the bed stares at the Seeker nearby, her red clothing blazing like a flame against the coffin-white surroundings.

"That's alright. People actually call me the Reaper."
"Hehe ... you're lying. The Reaper wouldn't wear Seekers' clothes."
Gerie doesn't argue. Her mind drifts to days prior—

"You'll represent the Grand Sanctum. Spend a few days there—just keep up appearances, show them the gods haven't forsaken them."
The Elder's tone carried authority. Though aware of Gerie's other identity, here at least, she could rightfully command as a senior.
"I'm not refusing, but surely there are others more suited..."
"I'm done debating with those old fossils about who's best for this. Just go."
"And get changed first. You look like a demon straight from hell, with those stains on your shoes and robes..."

Gerie hastily packed her belongings and departed.
For someone who waded through bloodshed daily, this sudden assignment to act as a true Seeker left her disoriented.
But the moment she arrived, she was greeted by a scent she knows all too well—that of death.

The Luminar led Gerie to a backroom sickbed where a frail girl lay.
"This orphan was abandoned as an infant and grew up within these walls. She's become a devout believer. But her illness ... after all these years, I fear she's reaching her limit. She won't last much longer... Poor child."
"... Who ... who's there?"
"Now, now, stay still, dear. The Luminar of the Grand Sanctum has come to see you!"
"I'm not really—"
"Ohhh... Holy Luminar... The gods have answered my prayers... I'm so blessed, so blessed..."
Gerie froze. Though seasoned in countless battles, nothing had ever thrown her off like this.
"... Just call me sis. I'm more like ... a trainee."
After a long silence, she forced out a composed greeting.

"Sis ... it hurts so much...!"
The girl's struggle and the artifact's warning alarm snap Gerie back to reality.
Though skilled in dealing wounds rather than healing them, she instinctively lets the girl grab onto her arm.
Red marks slowly rise where nails dig in, almost breaking her skin, as the girl gradually calms down.
"Sis ... I'm in so much pain..."
"Pain is proof that we're alive."
"Sis ... aren't you afraid of pain?"
"... I'm someone who needs to feel pain to survive. So if you're hurting, share some of the pain with me, okay?"
After a pause, the girl tightens her grip, as if responding to her expectations.
"Sis ... do you think of the gods when it hurts...?"
"Sis ... will the gods hear my prayers?"
"Sis ... why must we feel pain to stay alive?"
"Sis ... are you still here...?"

The ancient bells echo from afar while black-clad children assemble in the courtyard, their voices rising in sacred song under the Luminar's guidance.
Gerie bends down, her fingers tracing the scars along her arm before she lays white roses before the stone.
"This pilgrimage was cruel, but now, your suffering ends."
"May the God of Grace watch over you..."
She closes her eyes in devotion.
"... I will pray for you."
DiscIP.214037.4:
"Business is booming at this new doll shop, and there's something special about its dolls, or as experts phrase it—
"They've gained love and soul from all the careful attention they've received." Nazuna says this with a serious face, but everyone else is confused.
"So ... you're saying they take really good care of these dolls, right?" Fuyuka tries to make sense of Nazuna's claim.
"Exactly! And look at their accessories—it's like they were custom-made for each doll."
Nazuna transforms into an endless fountain of enthusiasm when it comes to dolls.
"Everything's just right, nothing feels out of place. You can only get that kind of perfection when there's tons of love involved!"
Nazuna gulps, then adds hopefully,
"... So, if we could just take one home..."

"Not happening! We've no space left at home. Besides, didn't we agree before coming here? Window shopping only." Kaede cuts off Nazuna's fantasy right there and then.
"Yeah, and if she actually gets started..." Nazuka lets out a sigh, "This place would be out of business by sunset. Right, Lord of the Prize Claw?"
That's right. This place has a special rule—you can't just buy any doll you want, you've got to try your luck with the claw machine!
"Hehe... Perfect chance to show off my skills. Better hope I go easy on them—"

"Hey there! Are you really good at the claw machine?" A child's innocent voice interrupts their conversation.
Four pairs of eyes land on their unexpected guest.
"Ah ... eh?" Nazuna blinks in confusion.
"I heard them call you the 'Lord of the Prize Claw,' so you must be super good, right?"
"Well, that's me..."
"Pretty please, Lord, help me get Mr. Roundy!"
"Wait, what?"

"Mr. Roundy"—no doubt the doll that's stolen this child's heart. He has nearly emptied his piggy bank trying to win it.

Push the button, drop the coin, then "click—", "buzz—," "clunk—."
"There you go, little one. Promise to keep it safe." Nazuna makes it look easy, passing "Mr. Roundy" to its eager new owner.
"Yay! Thank you so much! You really are the Lord of the Prize Claw!" The child dances away, hugging his doll.
"As expected of Nazuna..."
"... That was impressive."
"Just warming up today. Let's head back now. We can always return when we're in the mood—"

Just as they step outside, they notice the child from earlier being confronted by a girl, who seems determined to seize the Mr. Roundy he's carrying.
"Let go! Mr. Roundy was a special gift from the Lord of the Prize Claw to me!" The boy shields the doll with his whole body.
"You're the one who needs to let go! How dare you rename my Mr. Puff-Puff!" The girl tugs back just as fiercely.
"It's mine—"
"No, it's mine—"

"How should we deal with this?"
"... She's our expert on doll affairs." Following Nazuka's gaze, everyone turns to Nazuna.

"Hmm—! Something's definitely off here!" Without hesitation, she dashes toward the two. "Hey, you two! Stop right there!"
After some chaotic chasing, the three little ones finally calm down.
Turns out, the girl had lost a doll named Mr. Puff-Puff, and Mr. Puff-Puff looks exactly like Mr. Roundy.
"Not just the look... The stitching, the fuzzy spots ... even the tiny stains match up perfectly..."
Based on the girl's detailed account, Nazuna confirms that Mr. Roundy is Mr. Puff-Puff and vice versa.
"How is this even possible...?!"

"It must be the work of Ironclaw the Bandit!" the girl declares, her voice trembling with anger.
"Ironclaw the Bandit?"
According to the girl, this is an urban legend whispered among the children of the Ash District—a notorious thief who "steals children's beloved dolls."
Countless dolls have fallen victim to this villain, leaving a trail of heartbroken children who mourns the loss of their precious playmates. The girl before them is clearly one such victim.
"Ah, so ... that's what this shop's all about."
These dolls, each containing "love and soul,"—were they all taken from children?
How clever, hiding in plain sight all along.
"Leave it to me," Nazuna announces with burning passion. "In the name of the Lord of the Prize Claw, I will bring your companions back!"
"Nazuna seems ... really fired up about this," Kaede remarks, her expression caught between worry and admiration.
"... Leave her to it. We need to ready ourselves for a fight," Nazuka says quietly, cleaning her staff.
"A fight? Eh? Who are we fighting?" Fuyuka remains completely oblivious to the situation.

Later, the legend of Ironclaw the Bandit gained an interesting epilogue: A mysterious Lord of the Prize Claw appeared, single-handedly emptying every claw machine in the store, reuniting children with their beloved companions... As for the evil Ironclaw, he was shamefully brought to justice by the Lord of the Prize Claw!
What a truly delightful ending indeed.
DiscIP.214038.4:
"Ugh, It's sooo hot..."
Shia shifts restlessly on her bed, her hair tangled and damp against her neck and back, unable to find comfort in her afternoon nap.
Summer after summer, her long hair annoys her, yet she can never part with more than a trim.
Since sleep eludes her, perhaps a walk would serve better.
The moment she pushes the door open, a gush of heated air barges in. The beach feels like one giant frying pan under the sun.
This crazy summer heat—there's just no escaping it.

"Help me! Somebody—!"
"Please! Is anyone there?!"
A little girl struggles in the sea, fighting to keep herself from being swallowed by the waves. Her friends panic, frozen in place on the shore.
Without a moment's hesitation, Shia kicks off her shoes and dashes toward the water, ignoring the searing heat burning her soles.
Fortunately, the girl isn't far from shore. She's just too small and the sea got too deep for her within a few steps.
"Easy now, sweetheart. You're safe with me."
Shia scoops up the girl with both hands and quickly brings her ashore. Her companions immediately crowd around.
"Lila, are you alright...?"
"We're so sorry. We shouldn't have laughed at you..."
Shia hears that and frowns, "What happened?"
The children mumble and avoid eye contact. Swimming rings scattered on the beach suggest they came to play together.
"They didn't believe me about my fish friend."
The quiet little girl suddenly speaks up, her voice laden with grievances, "I saw this huge fish yesterday while fishing with Mom. It was a gray fish with a big head that kept following us."
"We made plans to meet today—it even waved its tail to say yes."
"I wanted to bring everyone here to play with it ... but we waited and waited, and it never showed up."
"So you went into the water to look for it?" Shia pieces it together, "You wanted to prove your friendship with the fish was real, didn't you?"

After appeasing the children, Shia leads them to rest in a shady spot under a tree, keeping them from getting into any more trouble.
"... Sis, I want you to have this swimming ring."
As Shia turns around and meet the little girl's hopeful gaze, memories from deep within stir.

As a child, she had been certain that she shared a special bond with the fish.
The crabs, shells, and starfish ... every sea creature was her companion.
Back then, unable to swim, she would sit in her swimming ring, drifting with the waves—the long summer days were finally bearable.

And so, Shia takes the swimming ring and walks toward the seaside, hand-in-hand with the young girl.
DiscIP.214039.4:
Karin felt a little down.
Although she was in the clear with her grandmother, a new annoyance had emerged.
A bright sky, a light breeze—today should have been perfect. She ought to be at the beach with Shia, digging for crabs, picking shell fishes, letting Shia take her surfing, then sitting on the sandy beach, eating barbecue as the sun went down...
But all that went out of the window. The beach was crawling with way too many people.
People who shouldn't even be here.

"Wow, that surf board looks awesome! Iris, time to give Loxy a new look!"
"But we don't have the budget for decoration. We have to land a big commission first..."
"Hehe, if Noya's interested, I can teach you the basics of surfing."
"Really? Yay!"

"You are the most popular Trekker of seafaring in Carlo right now, Shia. Could you tell us one of your cool sea stories?"
"Sea stories...?"
"Yeah! The wilder the better—the scarier the better★"

"When are they going to leave?!"
Karin sulked in the shade while Shia was surrounded by throng of people. She crushed her soda can into a twisted mess.
Her phone buzzed. A message from Amber.
"Why don't you come join us?"
Karin froze. A few days ago, out of politeness, she'd exchanged contacts with these people. She had zero intention of socializing with any of them.
And this Amber girl... She hardly ever spoke. Why was she approaching her now? As Karin hesitated, another message appeared:
"If you don't speak honestly, how will anyone know what you feel?"
Karin shot to her feet and spotted Amber by the drink stand, clearly watching her the whole time.

Karin chose the direct approach. She stormed up to Amber, locked eyes with her and snapped:
"Why are you watching me?"
Shock, confusion, panic—all flickered in Amber's gaze. Then, slowly, her face reddened.
"W-what's that supposed to mean..." Karin grew flustered as well. The sun beat down on her face, and she felt hotter and hotter.

"Amber, Karin—what are you two chatting about?"
"Eh? Why are your faces so red? They remind me of watermelons!"
"See you later." And with that, Amber just bolted.
"Hey! What do you mean by that!"
But Karin's demand went unanswered. She stared after Amber, unaware of the "danger" closing in behind her.
"Ow—my ear! Let go! Now!"
"Yay! I got her ears! Iris, you come try it, too!"
"Noya, maybe this isn't such a good idea..."
"It's a terrible idea! Just what do you think I am?!"
Karin fought back, but Noya was far too strong. Out of options, she finally shouted the words she'd been holding back all this time:
"Shia—Shia—stop playing with them—"
"Come save meeee!!"

In that instant, the girl's mind went blank.
She thought she was still searching for an answer, but her body had already instinctively reacted.

"Hah!"
Her fist stirred a gale. The steadfast enemy roared and raged, but was forced to stagger back.

The great monster had a tenacity that matched its size. A single punch was hardly enough to knock it down.
Lesser monsters kept swarming in, the fallen piling into mounds before her.

The fight dragged on.
But strangely—
She didn't feel like she could lose.
It was an emotion she was feeling for the first time, one she hesitated to name. It was—

... Trust ... faith ... reliance...
...And with that, a bit of self-confidence.

So this is what it feels like to fight as a team... She thought.
She had practiced it countless times, but it always felt like something from a dream.

Her heart pounded as sweat beaded on her brow.
The crisis was unlike any she had faced, the burden heavier than any she had shouldered.
And yet, she had never felt so free, so at ease, so alive.
She threw every punch with all her might, each one a thrilling release.

She knew where this strength came from.
From the person who gave her this precious chance, from the companions who silently guarded and guided her.
And now, it was her turn to protect them.
This thought alone filled her with endless courage.

She would not lose.
Not until the hulking enemy collapsed, not until cheers rose behind her, not until sunlight crept through the forest trees to warm her skin...
She looked down at her fist, where surging confidence had transformed into solid victory, and clenched it tight.
